description: This show explores the foundational concepts and workings of Azure SQL. We start by defining why you might decide to implement a hosted database in Azure SQL vs an on-premise solution; detailing some of the benefits of moving to Azure SQL. We then describe some of the more advanced benefits of using Azure SQL like using Resource Groups, Geo-Restore, Point-In-Time Restore, and Self-Service Restore. Finally they take a look at the performance tiers as well as Database Throughput Units or DTUs.
name: Azure SQL
subtitle: Relational Database-as-a-Service

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore and explain some of the foundational concepts and workings of Azure SQL. They start by defining why you might decide to implement a hosted database in Azure SQL vs an on-premise solution; detailing some of the benefits of moving to Azure SQL. Then they describe some of the more advanced benefits of using Azure SQL like using Resource Groups, Geo-Restore, Point-In-Time Restore, and Self-Service Restore. Finally they take a look at the performance tiers as well as Database Throughput Units or DTUs.

00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:09.960

that's actually a really good idea.

00:01:11.930 --> 00:01:13.690

00:01:13.690 --> 00:01:16.050
I mean if I've been in the business for
any length of time,

00:01:19.490 --> 00:01:21.818

00:01:46.710 --> 00:01:49.950

00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:53.530

00:02:14.370 --> 00:02:16.610

00:02:34.790 --> 00:02:37.185

us, there's a number of benefits,

00:02:46.924 --> 00:02:51.773

00:02:51.773 --> 00:02:54.613
And you're going to find that
you have a more secure and

00:02:54.613 --> 00:02:59.160
reliable deployment in Azure cloud than

00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:01.860

58
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:03.050

00:03:56.300 --> 00:03:59.390
Then once you move it into production,

00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:02.140

Generators, if you need to

00:04:46.855 --> 00:04:50.910

It's a.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through a few different ways in which you can migrate your on-premise database into Azure SQL. They start by showing you how to perform a scripted import using T-SQL from within Visual Studio. Then they demonstrate a migration using the SQL Management Studio Azure Deployment Wizard. Finally they perform a migration using BACPACs and monitor the progress of the migration.

714
00:34:22.207 --> 00:34:24.640
>> All right, well, I don't want
to get your expectations too high.

715
00:34:24.640 --> 00:34:26.700
I have never seen one go that fast.

716
00:34:26.700 --> 00:34:27.750
That is really amazing.

717
00:34:27.750 --> 00:34:30.340
But I've got a human resources
database right there.

718
00:34:30.340 --> 00:34:33.610
And if I jump back to my
SQL Management Studio, right,

719
00:34:33.610 --> 00:34:36.180
it's not gonna show it yet cuz it
doesn't refresh automatically, right?

720
00:34:36.180 --> 00:34:40.560
So here's my Azure cloud, and
I'm gonna refresh my database.

721
00:34:40.560 --> 00:34:44.630
And there's HumanResources, and if I
expand that out, then I can come in here,

722
00:34:44.630 --> 00:34:48.360
I can look for Tables,
and there's dbo.Employees.

723
00:34:48.360 --> 00:34:52.409
And if I do a quick Select Top 1,000 Rows,
we can look and

724
00:34:52.409 --> 00:34:55.810
it's gonna run that query, and
it's gonna export the rows, there we go.

725
00:34:55.810 --> 00:34:57.860
And there's my data.

726
00:34:57.860 --> 00:35:03.160
Right, so it actually brought data
along with it, and it's up and going.

727
00:35:03.160 --> 00:35:04.680
It's literally the fastest
one I've ever seen.

728
00:35:04.680 --> 00:35:05.810
It's amazing.

729
00:35:05.810 --> 00:35:09.000
One of the things I have in my notes to
explain to you guys as part of the show

730
00:35:09.000 --> 00:35:12.340
is, hey, it takes a long time,
it really stinks, and so

731
00:35:12.340 --> 00:35:13.350
here's a way to speed it up.

732
00:35:13.350 --> 00:35:14.900
But in my case,
I don't have to speed it up at all.

733
00:35:14.900 --> 00:35:16.930
I guess it was a really small database.

734
00:35:16.930 --> 00:35:21.910
One of the tricks that I use
to speed this up is sometimes

735
00:35:21.910 --> 00:35:26.430
I'll do a backpack like this but
not include the data, right?

736
00:35:26.430 --> 00:35:29.460
We'll use like the transact SQL scripts
that we talked about at the beginning.

737
00:35:29.460 --> 00:35:31.250
Bring those along to create
the infrastructure and

738
00:35:31.250 --> 00:35:34.300
then use bulk copy protocol to send
the data in on my own schedule.

739
00:35:34.300 --> 00:35:36.900
The problem with doing that is
you're limited by the DTUs.

740
00:35:36.900 --> 00:35:40.460
When Microsoft does it,
they're not limited by the DTUs.

741
00:35:40.460 --> 00:35:43.370
Restoring that backup doesn't
count as database throughput.

742
00:35:43.370 --> 00:35:44.960
It's something they do on the back end.

743
00:35:44.960 --> 00:35:46.090
That's why you get queued up.

744
00:35:46.090 --> 00:35:49.600
I guess I just lucked out and got to the,
maybe they knew I was doing the show,

745
00:35:49.600 --> 00:35:52.380
and they were like, let's prioritize
Don's so that he doesn't have to wait.

746
00:35:52.380 --> 00:35:54.850
>> You know they watch
the show from up there.

747
00:35:54.850 --> 00:35:55.590
>> Sometimes I wonder.

748
00:35:55.590 --> 00:35:59.340
So, but anyhow, this one's restored so
we don't have to speed it up at all.

749
00:35:59.340 --> 00:36:01.400
It's just gonna knock it out and
we're done.

750
00:36:01.400 --> 00:36:03.670
But now my database is up in Azure.

751
00:36:03.670 --> 00:36:06.520
And I still have my local database so
if I had flipped my local

752
00:36:06.520 --> 00:36:10.850
database into read only mode, people could
still be in it, just not making changes.

753
00:36:10.850 --> 00:36:14.303
And then I could redirect my clients up
to the one up in Azure, and off we go.

754
00:36:14.303 --> 00:36:15.522
If we use a DNS name space,

755
00:36:15.522 --> 00:36:18.799
we could just redirect the DNS name
space to point to the new database.

756
00:36:18.799 --> 00:36:21.670
And now people connect to it and
we just migrated to Azure,

757
00:36:21.670 --> 00:36:25.021
the whole database in tact,
all its components, all right there.

758
00:36:25.021 --> 00:36:28.958
Using the backpack method really is the
best way to get your database into Azure.

759
00:36:28.958 --> 00:36:30.869
>> Yeah, it seemed to be very,
very effective,

760
00:36:30.869 --> 00:36:33.082
even more effective than
you expected it to be, Don.

761
00:36:33.082 --> 00:36:33.699
>> [LAUGH] I know.

762
00:36:33.699 --> 00:36:36.629
>> So that is definitely
the way to go when it comes

763
00:36:36.629 --> 00:36:38.668
to importing these databases.

764
00:36:38.668 --> 00:36:41.593
And moving your database from
on premise up into Azure,

765
00:36:41.593 --> 00:36:44.370
that definitely seems to
be the way to rock it.

766
00:36:44.370 --> 00:36:46.710
Well Don, is there any parting
words of wisdom that you have for

767
00:36:46.710 --> 00:36:48.100
our viewers before we let them go?

768
00:36:48.100 --> 00:36:49.380
>> I think that's about it.

769
00:36:49.380 --> 00:36:55.220
One thing I will say is I'm going to use
the old X-Files quote, the trust no one.

770
00:36:55.220 --> 00:36:58.450
Even though my import was fully
successful, even though I didn't see any

771
00:36:58.450 --> 00:37:00.780
errors along the way, you always
wanna double check your data, right?

772
00:37:00.780 --> 00:37:04.220
Just verify that it is fully intact,
that things are working.

773
00:37:04.220 --> 00:37:07.280
Run some tests, don't just blindly flip
people over to this new database assuming

774
00:37:07.280 --> 00:37:08.340
it's all complete.

775
00:37:08.340 --> 00:37:11.980
Because we more than likely, we have other
things like firewall security rules that

776
00:37:11.980 --> 00:37:14.730
we have to set and stuff before
people can actually access it.

777
00:37:14.730 --> 00:37:17.450
So it might look fine, but
there might still be other problems.

778
00:37:17.450 --> 00:37:19.720
Definitely look in there for those and
make sure things are working.

779
00:37:19.720 --> 00:37:20.590
Do your testing.

780
00:37:20.590 --> 00:37:21.110
>> Awesome.

781
00:37:21.110 --> 00:37:22.970
Well, wise words by Mr. Don Pezet.

782
00:37:22.970 --> 00:37:24.760
Follow and love him, and know them.

783
00:37:24.760 --> 00:37:26.910
That being said, we've come to
the end of another great episode.

784
00:37:26.910 --> 00:37:27.800
Hopefully, you've enjoyed it.

785
00:37:27.800 --> 00:37:29.110
We've had a great time making it.

786
00:37:29.110 --> 00:37:30.960
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

787
00:37:30.960 --> 00:37:32.710
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

788
00:37:32.710 --> 00:37:33.364
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

789
00:37:33.364 --> 00:37:34.828
>> And we'll see you next time.

790
00:37:34.828 --> 00:37:41.650
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to create Tables and input data into an Azure SQL database. First they demonstrate creating tables in SQL and dive into some of the information that will be necessary for proper table creation and functionality. Then they show you how to create data to populate the tables as well as queries to retrieve data.
episodes.title: Tables and Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.023 --> 00:00:10.023
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.062 --> 00:00:16.950
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:18.810
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:19.960
And in today's episode,

5
00:00:19.960 --> 00:00:23.620
we're gonna continue on with
a little bit of Microsoft Azure SQL.

6
00:00:23.620 --> 00:00:27.930
And joining me in the studio today, one of
our resident experts on that topic is none

7
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:30.130
other than my good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:31.440
Don, welcome to the show.

9
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:32.380
And how's it going today?

10
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:33.370
>> It is going great Daniel.

11
00:00:33.370 --> 00:00:34.620
Thanks for having me back on the show.

12
00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:38.340
And in this episode, I want to take
a step off the beaten path, right?

13
00:00:38.340 --> 00:00:42.360
We've been talking a lot about Azure SQL
and getting our databases up in there,

14
00:00:42.360 --> 00:00:47.000
how to get connected to them,
how to migrate existing databases over.

15
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:52.150
But you might be tasked with creating
a brand new database from scratch.

16
00:00:52.150 --> 00:00:55.880
And the developers might be giving
you certain requirements of

17
00:00:55.880 --> 00:00:59.780
what they need available in that database
and it's up to you to create it.

18
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:05.280
So I want to start doing that dangerous
thing where a sysadmin starts to step into

19
00:01:05.280 --> 00:01:10.720
the developer side just a little bit and
give you guys a primer on Transact-SQL.

20
00:01:10.720 --> 00:01:13.990
The way that tables are built,
the way that data is stored in the table,

21
00:01:13.990 --> 00:01:17.830
the way that we insert data and
retrieve data from a table.

22
00:01:17.830 --> 00:01:22.030
These are things that a normal sysadmin
doesn't do, I guess a DevOps admin would.

23
00:01:22.030 --> 00:01:25.740
But a developer or a DBA, they're
absolutely gonna do this all the time.

24
00:01:25.740 --> 00:01:29.500
But you should have at least a basic
understanding of Transact-SQL and

25
00:01:29.500 --> 00:01:31.120
then how to interact with the server.

26
00:01:31.120 --> 00:01:33.880
Because there may be times where you
need to do that yourself, if for

27
00:01:33.880 --> 00:01:36.900
no other reason than to
verify the server is working.

28
00:01:36.900 --> 00:01:39.770
We're gonna talk about some other
technologies later on, like indexes and

29
00:01:39.770 --> 00:01:42.780
query optimization where we need to
have a basic understanding of queries.

30
00:01:42.780 --> 00:01:45.660
So I just wanna walk you guys
through that here in this episode.

31
00:01:45.660 --> 00:01:49.560
And we'll see something that we don't
normally have to worry about as an admin.

32
00:01:49.560 --> 00:01:51.890
>> Yeah Don.
This is actually a really good skill for

33
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:52.940
everybody out there watching.

34
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:58.312
If you don't have any SQL experience, this
is gonna be a good lesson for you guys.

35
00:01:58.312 --> 00:02:01.807
Because I was telling Don, I actually
look at Monster job posts because it's

36
00:02:01.807 --> 00:02:04.450
a horrible working environment here,
someone help me.

37
00:02:04.450 --> 00:02:09.750
[LAUGH] I watch to see what trends
are happening in the IT workplace,

38
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:12.480
and one of them is a normal
sys administrator or

39
00:02:12.480 --> 00:02:17.030
a sys admin is almost required to
have some level of SQL knowledge.

40
00:02:17.030 --> 00:02:19.960
So if you don't have any this
is a great show for you.

41
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:24.480
>> All right, so one of the problems that
we bump into is that developers, DBAs,

42
00:02:24.480 --> 00:02:28.050
they have this great habit of not
giving you enough information.

43
00:02:28.050 --> 00:02:30.150
Asking you to do something and
not giving you enough information.

44
00:02:30.150 --> 00:02:33.290
And if you don't know what to get,
you start to have some problems, right?

45
00:02:33.290 --> 00:02:34.800
So let me just give you an example.

46
00:02:34.800 --> 00:02:38.070
Maybe, well, I have a human resources
database that I've been using.

47
00:02:38.070 --> 00:02:41.830
And in the human resources database,
I've got a table for employees.

48
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:43.978
And I might want a table for
departments, and so on.

49
00:02:43.978 --> 00:02:45.809
I might want different tables for
different things for

50
00:02:45.809 --> 00:02:47.460
how my company's organized.

51
00:02:47.460 --> 00:02:50.520
And so a developer tells me, they say,
hey, I need a table there with employees,

52
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:55.450
and it needs first name and
last name, phone number, and address.

53
00:02:55.450 --> 00:02:59.015
And so, in my mind,
I start thinking spreadsheet-style, right,

54
00:02:59.015 --> 00:03:00.618
I think like Microsoft Excel.

55
00:03:00.618 --> 00:03:02.450
Here, I'll fire up Excel.

56
00:03:02.450 --> 00:03:06.620
And, so if I were to create something in
Excel like this, I might have first name

57
00:03:06.620 --> 00:03:11.870
and last name,
I might have department, phone number.

58
00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:15.390
If I want address,
I might have Address1, so I'll try and

59
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:18.610
spell it right, Address2 and so on.

60
00:03:18.610 --> 00:03:21.682
And then in table type fashion
I would just add each person.

61
00:03:21.682 --> 00:03:27.626
So I might say Don Pezet, department
is Edutainers, edutainer department.

62
00:03:27.626 --> 00:03:32.571
Phone number, 555-1212, right, good old
trusty Hollywood number, and so on, right?

63
00:03:32.571 --> 00:03:33.895
So we specified all of that information.

64
00:03:33.895 --> 00:03:37.010
All I needed to know were the column
names, and I'm in business.

65
00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:40.240
But SQL needs to know more.

66
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:41.990
Microsoft SQL, when it stores its data,

67
00:03:41.990 --> 00:03:45.240
it's storing it in a highly
optimized manner, and so

68
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:48.530
there's a lot of additional information
we need to know to get the set right.

69
00:03:49.630 --> 00:03:52.359
For example, when I have a first name,

70
00:03:52.359 --> 00:03:57.180
what's the maximum amount of
characters I might use for first name?

71
00:03:57.180 --> 00:03:59.150
Well, my first name's only three letters.

72
00:03:59.150 --> 00:04:01.170
So that's not gonna take a lot of
space on the hard drive, is it?

73
00:04:01.170 --> 00:04:02.020
It's just three letters.

74
00:04:02.020 --> 00:04:03.270
Pow, done.

75
00:04:03.270 --> 00:04:05.630
But, your name is Daniel.

76
00:04:05.630 --> 00:04:07.530
I'm informing you on this,
in case you didn't know.

77
00:04:07.530 --> 00:04:09.750
So you've got six letters.

78
00:04:09.750 --> 00:04:12.370
So you take twice as much storage as me,
right?

79
00:04:12.370 --> 00:04:15.750
Because, well, not necessarily,
it all comes down to the bytes, and so on.

80
00:04:15.750 --> 00:04:19.070
But you could potentially take twice
as much storage as me cuz your name is

81
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:20.110
twice as long.

82
00:04:20.110 --> 00:04:24.700
Now, with SQL, when it writes this data to
the hard drive, it has to make a decision.

83
00:04:24.700 --> 00:04:29.490
Do I provision out a block of data
that's the same for everybody, or

84
00:04:29.490 --> 00:04:34.970
do I provision a block of data that's
small and grows as it fills up, okay?

85
00:04:34.970 --> 00:04:38.870
Well, if I provision a block of data for
everybody, let's say that I said

86
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:42.540
everybody in my company has 250
characters for their first name, right?

87
00:04:42.540 --> 00:04:44.650
You're gonna have 250 characters.

88
00:04:44.650 --> 00:04:48.720
My name's Don, so I just wasted
247 characters worth of space.

89
00:04:49.730 --> 00:04:55.320
But by setting that block of storage aside
for me, I can increase my name or decrease

90
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:58.710
my name in the future and it wouldn't
affect database performance at all.

91
00:04:58.710 --> 00:05:00.040
That space is already set aside.

92
00:05:01.230 --> 00:05:05.110
I could have also done a variable
size where we said, all right,

93
00:05:05.110 --> 00:05:08.370
it's going to be up to 250 characters.

94
00:05:08.370 --> 00:05:11.750
Now when I put in three characters,
it just takes three characters of space.

95
00:05:11.750 --> 00:05:15.230
But if I decide to increase my name,
let's say I go to Donald.

96
00:05:15.230 --> 00:05:16.550
And when I do that,

97
00:05:16.550 --> 00:05:18.910
it might be out of room at the spot
where that data is written right now.

98
00:05:18.910 --> 00:05:21.730
So now it's got to move it to
a different place on the hard drive, and

99
00:05:21.730 --> 00:05:23.310
that affects performance.

100
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:27.080
Whenever you change the size of
your data on a variable data type,

101
00:05:27.080 --> 00:05:28.590
it affects performance.

102
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:34.320
So, it's more efficient, but hurts
performance, versus doing a static set

103
00:05:34.320 --> 00:05:40.540
of size for each person is not efficient,
but is great for performance.

104
00:05:40.540 --> 00:05:41.992
These are the choices we have to make.

105
00:05:41.992 --> 00:05:45.045
And if somebody asks you to create a table
and they don't tell you that information,

106
00:05:45.045 --> 00:05:46.507
you've gotta figure it out yourself and

107
00:05:46.507 --> 00:05:49.259
that's not realistic cuz you don't
know how they're gonna use that data.

108
00:05:50.260 --> 00:05:53.750
So I wanna show you guys how to
make a table, and I wanna show you

109
00:05:53.750 --> 00:05:57.060
the various data types and other things
that we need to know to ask about.

110
00:05:57.060 --> 00:05:59.660
When somebody says, hey,
I need a table, these are the follow up

111
00:05:59.660 --> 00:06:02.900
questions we need to have before we start
creating them and turning them loose.

112
00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:06.090
What I normally say is, here,
let me give you a SQL admin account,

113
00:06:06.090 --> 00:06:06.855
create it yourself.

114
00:06:06.855 --> 00:06:08.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what I like, right?

115
00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:11.280
But in this world of dev ops,
sometimes they expect us to do it and so

116
00:06:11.280 --> 00:06:12.410
now we've gotta get
a little more involved.

117
00:06:12.410 --> 00:06:18.430
So let me jump into my Azure environment,
and then I'm in my SQL Management Studio.

118
00:06:18.430 --> 00:06:20.890
So just like we've been
most of this series.

119
00:06:20.890 --> 00:06:25.290
And I'm gonna take that human
resources database that I have.

120
00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:30.260
It doesn't have much in it,
I created a table called Employees, right?

121
00:06:30.260 --> 00:06:31.720
But let's say I didn't have that table.

122
00:06:31.720 --> 00:06:34.810
I'm just gonna delete
that turkey out of there.

123
00:06:34.810 --> 00:06:39.520
And once I get rid of that,
so I'll delete it and

124
00:06:39.520 --> 00:06:41.370
we'll recreate that Employees table.

125
00:06:41.370 --> 00:06:45.210
All right so, oh shoot actually I'm
doing that in the cloud, all right.

126
00:06:45.210 --> 00:06:46.130
Well, that's fine.

127
00:06:46.130 --> 00:06:50.092
So, I just deleted that table out of there
and I wanna create a new table, okay?

128
00:06:50.092 --> 00:06:52.970
So, [LAUGH] I had an oh
shoot panic moment there.

129
00:06:52.970 --> 00:06:56.600
I delete tables off my local machine all
the time, but when I delete something from

130
00:06:56.600 --> 00:06:59.010
the cloud I always have that freakout of,
is that in production?

131
00:06:59.010 --> 00:07:01.480
And I have to remember, no,
that's my test database, what do I care?

132
00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:07.530
So, if I wanna create a table, all I have
to do is right-click on that Tables menu

133
00:07:07.530 --> 00:07:10.210
and, if I can figure out where
my mouse is, there we go.

134
00:07:10.210 --> 00:07:12.480
Right click on Tables,
go to New, then Table.

135
00:07:13.480 --> 00:07:16.180
There's special tables,
like memory optimized tables,

136
00:07:16.180 --> 00:07:17.240
that we won't get into here.

137
00:07:17.240 --> 00:07:19.830
But you can create really efficient ones
if you know there's going to be massive

138
00:07:19.830 --> 00:07:20.800
amounts of data.

139
00:07:20.800 --> 00:07:22.480
But I'm going to create a new table.

140
00:07:22.480 --> 00:07:23.670
And when I create a new table,

141
00:07:23.670 --> 00:07:27.680
I get this nice little graphical
user interface sort of, right?

142
00:07:27.680 --> 00:07:32.680
And it's asking me to specify the name
of the column, and the data type.

143
00:07:32.680 --> 00:07:34.640
So I might wanna create

00:29:04.940 --> 00:29:07.306
SQL, the standard query language,

604
00:29:07.306 --> 00:29:12.360
it's supported by a lot of different
systems, Oracle, Microsoft, MySQL.

605
00:29:12.360 --> 00:29:15.923
But Microsoft uses what's called
Transact-SQL where they've actually added

606
00:29:15.923 --> 00:29:17.180
some stuff on to it.

607
00:29:17.180 --> 00:29:19.250
So make sure you look for
Transact-SQL stuff.

608
00:29:19.250 --> 00:29:21.850
Microsoft on their own website has
a ton of great documentation on

609
00:29:21.850 --> 00:29:22.360
how to run these.

610
00:29:22.360 --> 00:29:24.570
So if you wanna learn more about it,
it's out there.

611
00:29:24.570 --> 00:29:27.170
But for a sys admin,
we really just need to know some basics.

612
00:29:27.170 --> 00:29:29.570
The insert command and the select command.

613
00:29:29.570 --> 00:29:31.580
Putting data in and getting data out.

614
00:29:31.580 --> 00:29:32.560
Those are the two big ones.

615
00:29:32.560 --> 00:29:33.110
>> That's awesome.

616
00:29:33.110 --> 00:29:36.470
Don, thank you so much for
those demonstrations, those explanations.

617
00:29:36.470 --> 00:29:40.590
That can really help you if you're
not a database guy, you're not a DBA,

618
00:29:40.590 --> 00:29:44.670
well now you have at least a little bit to
sink your teeth into so that you can at

619
00:29:44.670 --> 00:29:49.410
least dive into that pool from time to
time, dip your toe in it, as it were.

620
00:29:49.410 --> 00:29:50.780
Don, thank you very much for that.

621
00:29:50.780 --> 00:29:53.130
And thank you everyone for watching.

622
00:29:53.130 --> 00:29:55.100
We have come to the end
of this here episode.

623
00:29:55.100 --> 00:29:56.750
So we're gonna sign off.

624
00:29:56.750 --> 00:29:59.150
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

625
00:29:59.150 --> 00:29:59.810
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

626
00:29:59.810 --> 00:30:01.401
>> And we'll see you next time.

627
00:30:01.401 --> 00:30:07.490

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explore automation of tasks in Azure SQL. They start by explaining how to enable automation beginning with the SQL Server Agent. Then they jump into Azure and create an Automation Account which will be needed to create automated tasks for SQL. Here they introduce you to Runbooks which works inside of PowerShell to create the scripts for automation. Then they upload, test, publish, and schedule a task.
episodes.title: Azure Automation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.078 --> 00:00:16.629
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.629 --> 00:00:19.618
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:19.618 --> 00:00:23.570
we are continuing down that Azure SQL path
that we've been blazing the trail on.

5
00:00:23.570 --> 00:00:24.220
And joining us yet

00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:27.980
again right here in the studio is none

7
00:00:27.980 --> 00:00:30.860
Don, welcome back to the show and
well, how are you doing today?

8
00:00:30.860 --> 00:00:31.580
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

9
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:32.330
Thanks for having me back.

10
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:36.140
And once again jumping into that world of
Microsoft Azure SQL today we're gonna be

11
00:00:36.140 --> 00:00:42.010
taking a look at something that a lot of
people describe as a shortcoming in Azure,

12
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:45.210
which is automating
activities in Azure SQL.

13
00:00:45.210 --> 00:00:48.610
Things that we don't want to have to
manually run or be there for, we just want

14
00:00:48.610 --> 00:00:52.140
the server to run for us in the background
so that we don't have to worry about it.

15
00:00:52.140 --> 00:00:54.614
Automation is a great way to
stabilize your environment and

16
00:00:54.614 --> 00:00:56.503
make sure that things happen consistently.

17
00:00:56.503 --> 00:00:59.688
Unfortunately, Azure kind of got a rocky
start on this one in the beginning,

18
00:00:59.688 --> 00:01:02.432
so a lot of people think you can't do it,
but you actually can, and

19
00:01:02.432 --> 00:01:05.350
that's what we're going to take
a look at here in this episode.

20
00:01:05.350 --> 00:01:09.240
>> Yeah, one of my philosophies when it
comes to computers and networking and

21
00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:12.430
things of that nature is automation is
our friend, it's the whole purpose,

22
00:01:12.430 --> 00:01:16.870
we created the computer so it can do
things that I don't either want to do or

23
00:01:16.870 --> 00:01:20.570
I just can't do because it's too
complex for the human being,

24
00:01:20.570 --> 00:01:23.960
to be able to accomplish,
in any kind of relative amount of time.

25
00:01:23.960 --> 00:01:25.470
So, this is going to be
an interesting show.

26
00:01:25.470 --> 00:01:28.422
Where can we allow SQL or
Azure, should I say,

27
00:01:28.422 --> 00:01:31.777
to take some of my
responsibilities off of my plate.

28
00:01:31.777 --> 00:01:36.207
Automate some things, and that frees me
up to do other things maybe improve my

29
00:01:36.207 --> 00:01:38.600
network or check out new technology.

30
00:01:38.600 --> 00:01:40.300
So Don, I'm looking forward to this,

31
00:01:40.300 --> 00:01:44.490
I guess this is a real
hard thing to segway into.

32
00:01:44.490 --> 00:01:46.660
Where in the world do we begin with this?

33
00:01:46.660 --> 00:01:49.595
>> Let's start with some of the things
that we might wanna automate right.

34
00:01:49.595 --> 00:01:54.120
Now with an on-premise SQL server,
there is a ton of stuff we wanna automate.

35
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:57.703
You wanna automate backups, I don't want
to manually run a backup every day, I

36
00:01:57.703 --> 00:02:01.251
want it cuz I might be doing transactional
log back ups every fifteen minutes.

37
00:02:01.251 --> 00:02:02.688
I don't want to have to do that.

38
00:02:02.688 --> 00:02:05.550
I guess maybe if I'm an hourly
employee that would be great, but

39
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:06.830
if you're salary it sucks.

40
00:02:06.830 --> 00:02:10.320
So you don't wanna do that so
we need a system where it will

41
00:02:10.320 --> 00:02:12.110
automatically do a back
up every fifteen minutes,

42
00:02:12.110 --> 00:02:17.290
or I might want to automate
updating my indexes.

43
00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:19.290
Right?
When we create indexes,

44
00:02:19.290 --> 00:02:23.540
indexes really improve the performance
of a query, but they fragment over time.

45
00:02:23.540 --> 00:02:27.581
And so we either need to rebuild or
reorganize those indexes every so often,

46
00:02:27.581 --> 00:02:30.371
once a day, once a week,
whatever our interval is.

47
00:02:30.371 --> 00:02:34.940
Those are tasks that we want to
occur on a recurring schedule.

48
00:02:34.940 --> 00:02:37.400
Right, backups are really
the greatest example.

49
00:02:37.400 --> 00:02:40.790
Well, when Microsoft rolled on Azure SQL,
they said,

50
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:44.940
let´s take these tasks that people
automate, and let´s just do it for them.

51
00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:45.900
And so backups,

52
00:02:45.900 --> 00:02:50.150
they back your server up once every
minute, I mean that´s pretty good right.

53
00:02:50.150 --> 00:02:53.340
So, I don´t have to automate
backups anymore they do it for me.

54
00:02:53.340 --> 00:02:56.770
Or database integrity checks,
I don't do that anymore.

55
00:02:56.770 --> 00:02:58.370
Microsoft does it for me.

56
00:02:58.370 --> 00:03:01.910
Those types of activities, they're done.

57
00:03:01.910 --> 00:03:04.503
And so when Microsoft originally
rolled out Azure SQL,

58
00:03:04.503 --> 00:03:07.428
they said you know we've already
automated all this stuff, so

59
00:03:07.428 --> 00:03:10.060
there's really no point
in doing any automation.

60
00:03:10.060 --> 00:03:10.820
We've already done it.

61
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:11.630
That's it.

62
00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:12.645
And that's how they left it.

63
00:03:12.645 --> 00:03:16.261
But the problem is there are some
things they don't do like defragmenting

64
00:03:16.261 --> 00:03:17.690
the indexes, right?

65
00:03:17.690 --> 00:03:18.401
They don't do that.

66
00:03:18.401 --> 00:03:21.406
And so the index just sit there and
they get fragmented and

67
00:03:21.406 --> 00:03:24.250
it's up to us to defragment them manually.

68
00:03:24.250 --> 00:03:25.822
Well, in an on premises server,

69
00:03:25.822 --> 00:03:28.976
you actually have a great technology
called the SQL Server Agent.

70
00:03:28.976 --> 00:03:30.091
In the SQL Server Agent,

71
00:03:30.091 --> 00:03:34.070
it's just a little process that runs
in the background on most SQL servers.

72
00:03:34.070 --> 00:03:36.010
And you give jobs to do and
you can tell what to do.

73
00:03:36.010 --> 00:03:39.540
So you can say, hey, defragment
this indexes every Sunday at 1 AM.

74
00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:41.870
And do a backup everyday every midnight.

75
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:44.137
And do s transaction log every 15 minutes.

76
00:03:44.137 --> 00:03:47.570
You just tell the agent to do it,
and the agent does it.

77
00:03:47.570 --> 00:03:49.930
Just runs the background and
those the job.

78
00:03:49.930 --> 00:03:53.767
But the agent isn't present in Azure SQL,
it's not there.

79
00:03:53.767 --> 00:03:58.520
So, if you want to continue using the
sequel server, as the SQL server agent,

80
00:03:58.520 --> 00:04:01.820
there we go,
if you want to keep using that.

81
00:04:01.820 --> 00:04:07.180
Your only option is not to use as your
SQL but instead to deploy SQL as your VM.

82
00:04:07.180 --> 00:04:07.690
Right?

83
00:04:07.690 --> 00:04:10.060
And now you have take over
the management of all the stuff,

84
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:12.790
you have to worry about back-ups, it's
basically a non-premises server at that

85
00:04:12.790 --> 00:04:15.650
point, just hosted in the Cloud, right.

86
00:04:15.650 --> 00:04:18.686
But Microsoft picked up on this pretty
quick that there was a problem.

87
00:04:18.686 --> 00:04:21.979
And what they did, is it took them a
little longer to solve the problem because

88
00:04:21.979 --> 00:04:24.450
they didn't want to just roll
out the agent in Azure SQL.

89
00:04:24.450 --> 00:04:28.095
They said, look,
automating SQL is one thing, but

90
00:04:28.095 --> 00:04:31.805
there's actually stuff people
wanna automate all through Azure.

91
00:04:31.805 --> 00:04:35.835
And so, what they created was
a tool called Azure Automation.

92
00:04:35.835 --> 00:04:38.458
And Azure Automation is not just for SQL.

93
00:04:38.458 --> 00:04:43.015
You can use it to automate activities
all throughout your Azure portal.

94
00:04:43.015 --> 00:04:45.525
You can use it to automate
creating virtual machines,

95
00:04:45.525 --> 00:04:50.370
you can automate enabling or
disabling networks, sending out

96
00:04:50.370 --> 00:04:55.090
reports on machine performance,
but you can also use it for SQL.

97
00:04:55.090 --> 00:04:59.444
So if you wanna automate activities in
SQL, you have to move away from the old

98
00:04:59.444 --> 00:05:02.316
SQL server agent, and
move to Azure automation.

99
00:05:02.316 --> 00:05:04.390
And so I wanna show you that process,
how it works.

100
00:05:04.390 --> 00:05:05.260
This is a pretty new one.

101
00:05:05.260 --> 00:05:08.560
It was in preview up until
just a couple of weeks ago,

102
00:05:08.560 --> 00:05:10.870
well when this was filmed at least.

103
00:05:10.870 --> 00:05:13.900
And so it is one of their newer
services but it's out there now.

104
00:05:13.900 --> 00:05:16.890
It's in production, it's ready to rock,
and it is powerful,

105
00:05:16.890 --> 00:05:19.210
which also means it's kinda hard to use.

106
00:05:19.210 --> 00:05:20.650
[LAUGH] As most powerful things are.

107
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:24.240
So, I wanna show you the process of
getting automation enabled, how it works,

108
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:26.110
how we set it up for SQL.

109
00:05:26.110 --> 00:05:28.750
But just keep in the back of your
mind that you can use this for

110
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:32.080
a lot more than SQL, even though
that's what we're gonna focus on here.

111
00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:34.460
So let's start with just
getting this thing set up.

112
00:05:34.460 --> 00:05:37.390
The first thing is we need
to turn on Azure Automation.

113
00:05:37.390 --> 00:05:41.350
And the way you turn it on is by creating
what's called a automation account.

114
00:05:41.350 --> 00:05:45.350
Just like with storage accounts,
it's not really like a user account or

115
00:05:45.350 --> 00:05:46.560
even a financial account.

116
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:49.520
It's just a, they call it a storage
account because it's the part of your

117
00:05:49.520 --> 00:05:52.150
account that's storing things,
automation's the same way.

118
00:05:52.150 --> 00:05:54.270
So I'm gonna create an automation account,
and

119
00:05:54.270 --> 00:05:59.080
inside of that account we're gonna create
things like credentials and jobs and

120
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:02.560
stuff for them to do, and
all the things that we automate.

121
00:06:02.560 --> 00:06:03.500
We're gonna place in there, but

122
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:05.460
the first thing is to create
that automation account.

123
00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:08.840
So I'm gonna jump over
into my Azure portal,

124
00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:10.420
which I've completely failed to do.

125
00:06:10.420 --> 00:06:12.619
Here we go, so
I'm gonna jump over to my Azure portal.

126
00:06:12.619 --> 00:06:17.054
And you usually won't see automation
in your pinned list by default.

127
00:06:17.054 --> 00:06:19.640
So you may need to go up here to New.

128
00:06:19.640 --> 00:06:21.150
And you can hunt and find it.

129
00:06:21.150 --> 00:06:22.980
I think it's under like management or
something.

130
00:06:22.980 --> 00:06:24.140
Let's see if we can find
it under management.

131
00:06:24.140 --> 00:06:26.290
I normally just type in
the search automation.

132
00:06:26.290 --> 00:06:27.960
But yeah, there it is under management.

133
00:06:27.960 --> 00:06:31.820
So I went to New, Management, Automation.

134
00:06:31.820 --> 00:06:33.320
And when you click on Automation,

135
00:06:33.320 --> 00:06:35.850
this is gonna take you to the screen
where you can enable automation.

136
00:06:35.850 --> 00:06:39.380
Now, it's out of preview for me.

137
00:06:39.380 --> 00:06:41.510
Microsoft rolls these things out in waves.

138
00:06:41.510 --> 00:06:43.430
And so
if you're watching this a month from now,

139
00:06:43.430 --> 00:06:45.250
you'll go straight to this screen.

140
00:06:45.250 --> 00:06:48.970
But if you're watching this episode right
now, live, it's possibly your account

141
00:06:48.970 --> 00:06:52.420
still has it in preview, and when you
click on automation, the first thing

142
00:06:52.420 --> 00:06:55.060
you'll get is it's asking you whether you
want to activate the preview feature.

143
00:06:55.060 --> 00:06:57.030
And so you just say yes to that,
and then you'll see this screen.

144
00:06:57.030 --> 00:06:59.250
For everybody else,
you'll see this screen right here.

145
00:06:59.250 --> 00:07:01.950
Or, we can add an Automation account.

146
00:07:01.950 --> 00:07:02.520
Okay?

147
00:07:02.520 --> 00:07:05.488
Just like a Storage account,
this is a service that's going to

148
00:07:05.488 --> 00:07:08.864
run in the background up in Azure and
perform my automated activities.

149
00:07:08.864 --> 00:07:10.440
So, I need to give it a name.

150
00:07:10.440 --> 00:07:13.620
And, if this one is just supporting
a particular SQL Server,

151
00:07:13.620 --> 00:07:15.150
I might want to name it after that.

152
00:07:15.150 --> 00:07:18.080
Or, if it's going to be supporting all of
my environments, just give it a name so

153
00:07:18.080 --> 00:07:19.530
you can recognize it.

154
00:07:19.530 --> 00:07:23.380
I usually break it down based on server,
but you don't have to do it that way.

155
00:07:23.380 --> 00:07:25.941
My SQL server is called itprotvdemo1.

156
00:07:25.941 --> 00:07:28.310
And so, I might choose to call it that.

157
00:07:28.310 --> 00:07:32.460
And see it's letting me duplicate the name
of a server, cuz it's a separate process.

158
00:07:32.460 --> 00:07:38.750
So, this is gonna automate activities for
databases residing on itprotvdemo1.

159
00:07:38.750 --> 00:07:41.482
Or if I'm automating just things for
sample dv2 or something,

160
00:07:41.482 --> 00:07:43.057
I might put the name of the database.

161
00:07:43.057 --> 00:07:44.980
Whatever it is that helps you
remember what this is for.

162
00:07:46.600 --> 00:07:49.220
Then we can pick the resource
group that it's tied to.

163
00:07:49.220 --> 00:07:50.760
And because I'm managing SQL servers,

164
00:07:50.760 --> 00:07:52.671
I wanna put this in
the resource group with those.

165
00:07:52.671 --> 00:07:55.368
And that way,
if I ever delete the resource group,

166
00:07:55.368 --> 00:07:58.462
that'll knock out the servers and
the automation tasks.

167
00:07:58.462 --> 00:08:00.784
I never wanna have a situation
where I delete a server and

168
00:08:00.784 --> 00:08:04.048
I still have automation tasks that were
available for that server cuz they're

169
00:08:04.048 --> 00:08:06.914
gonna start failing and it's gonna
generate a lot of log messages and

170
00:08:06.914 --> 00:08:09.000
just generally annoy the heck out of you.

171
00:08:09.000 --> 00:08:10.390
So, I like to group those together.

172
00:08:10.390 --> 00:08:12.450
So, I'm gonna pick a resource group and

173
00:08:12.450 --> 00:08:17.780
I'll put those in my
ITProTV SQL demo down here.

174
00:08:17.780 --> 00:08:19.450
It's tied to my subscription.

175
00:08:19.450 --> 00:08:22.660
My region, for whatever reason,
defaulted to Japan East.

176
00:08:22.660 --> 00:08:24.080
I'm not quite sure why.

177
00:08:24.080 --> 00:08:25.590
>> Trying to give Japan
a little more love.

178
00:08:25.590 --> 00:08:26.350
>> I guess so.

179
00:08:26.350 --> 00:08:28.730
That must be the least busy
data center right now.

180
00:08:28.730 --> 00:08:31.550
So I'm gonna pick East US 2 which
is where all my SQL servers are.

181
00:08:31.550 --> 00:08:34.450
But your automation account
doesn't actually have to be in

182
00:08:34.450 --> 00:08:36.078
the same region as your servers.

183
00:08:36.078 --> 00:08:37.990
You can pick a different
region if you want.

184
00:08:37.990 --> 00:08:41.410
I normally try and keep them together
just for management purposes.

185
00:08:41.410 --> 00:08:44.890
The reality is if the servers fail, the
automation tasks are gonna fail anyway.

186
00:08:44.890 --> 00:08:46.870
And if the automation fails,

187
00:08:46.870 --> 00:08:49.310
then the automatic tasks aren't gonna
run even though the database is up.

188
00:08:49.310 --> 00:08:51.190
So if they're in the same data center or

189
00:08:51.190 --> 00:08:53.730
if they're in separate data centers
doesn't really make a difference on this.

190
00:08:53.730 --> 00:08:57.030
I'm not improving or
decreasing my availability.

191
00:08:58.740 --> 00:09:01.910
And then I can just review
my default settings

192
00:09:01.910 --> 00:09:03.920
which there's not a whole
heck of a lot here.

193
00:09:03.920 --> 00:09:07.550
The only real option I have is whether
I want to create a tutorial run book.

194
00:09:07.550 --> 00:09:09.190
All right now, what is a run book?

195
00:09:10.360 --> 00:09:12.710
With Azure automation you create jobs.

196
00:09:12.710 --> 00:09:16.300
And a job is, well they don't call
them jobs, they call them run books.

197
00:09:16.300 --> 00:09:18.040
I gotta makes sure I use
the right terminology.

198
00:09:18.040 --> 00:09:24.220
So, what a run book is, is the task,
is the activity that you want performed.

199
00:09:24.220 --> 00:09:28.800
So if I want to defragment
the indexes of a SQL database,

200
00:09:28.800 --> 00:09:30.690
I'm going to have to write a run book.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel take a look at exporting data from your Azure SQL database. First they talk about when you might need to export an entire database and then walk you through the methods to that end. Then they discuss how you might export pieces of data like tables from your database. They show you a few formats that you might export the data as such as XML, CSV, and even into an Excel spreadsheet.

Now Don, this really seems like

00:14:34.340 --> 00:14:37.950

297
00:14:40.060 --> 00:14:41.900
>> Well, a lot of people do that.

298
00:14:41.900 --> 00:14:44.550
A lot of people say, I've got this
query that's taxing the system so

299
00:14:44.550 --> 00:14:45.620
I create an index for it.

300
00:14:45.620 --> 00:14:48.120
Now it's running great,
they set it and they forget it.

301
00:14:48.120 --> 00:14:49.580
They never come back to it.

302
00:14:49.580 --> 00:14:53.790
Well, the problem is, indexes,
they're like a houseplant.

303
00:14:53.790 --> 00:14:56.060
You gotta feed 'em, you gotta water them.

304
00:14:56.060 --> 00:15:01.030
Every time you edit, the underline data
of a table, every time you add a new row,

305
00:15:01.030 --> 00:15:06.100
every time you update an existing row, an
index has to be updated to reflect that.

306
00:15:06.100 --> 00:15:09.120
If I delete a row, that record
needs to be taken out of the index.

307
00:15:09.120 --> 00:15:10.790
So indexes are updating all the time.

308
00:15:10.790 --> 00:15:12.950
They're adding stuff and
deleting stuff, and

309
00:15:12.950 --> 00:15:16.568
they're storing things in pages, and
those pages are of a different size, and

310
00:15:16.568 --> 00:15:18.680
when a page fills up it
has to create a new page.

311
00:15:18.680 --> 00:15:20.232
Well, on the hard drive,

312
00:15:20.232 --> 00:15:23.912
the space right next to the first
page might not be available.

313
00:15:23.912 --> 00:15:26.074
And so it's got to place that
page somewhere else, and

314
00:15:26.074 --> 00:15:29.415
as certain records get delete, there might
not be enough room to write a new record.

315
00:15:29.415 --> 00:15:33.806
The new record has to go somewhere
else too, and what you end up with,

316
00:15:33.806 --> 00:15:35.493
is index fragmentation.

317
00:15:35.493 --> 00:15:40.377
No matter how well-oiled your database is
if you're adding and deleting records,

318
00:15:40.377 --> 00:15:43.761
over time your database indexes
will become fragmented.

319
00:15:43.761 --> 00:15:46.120
I shouldn't say database,
it's really table index.

320
00:15:46.120 --> 00:15:48.050
Your table index will become fragmented.

321
00:15:48.050 --> 00:15:50.129
Now, fragmentation is
not always a bad thing.

322
00:15:50.129 --> 00:15:53.062
I know, if you're a system admin,
all these years people are like,

323
00:15:53.062 --> 00:15:54.338
defragment your hard drive!

324
00:15:54.338 --> 00:15:58.754
Fragmentation's bad, and
that was true under magnetic media.

325
00:15:58.754 --> 00:16:01.066
Under SSD, your seek time is so small and

326
00:16:01.066 --> 00:16:05.300
you're not having to move ahead to
read different places on a hard drive.

327
00:16:05.300 --> 00:16:07.940
You don't have a mechanical
arm that's moving around.

328
00:16:07.940 --> 00:16:10.900
You just have electronics that says go
to this address, go to that address.

329
00:16:10.900 --> 00:16:14.610
So fragmentation on SSD
is not really a big deal.

330
00:16:14.610 --> 00:16:19.450
But, indexes, as they begin to fragment,
start to consume a lot more space.

331
00:16:19.450 --> 00:16:22.730
In Azure, you have a limit to
the amount of space you got.

332
00:16:22.730 --> 00:16:27.060
So, if you've only got 250 gigs available,
maybe you did an S0 standard instance for

333
00:16:27.060 --> 00:16:29.130
your database, you have 250 gigs.

334
00:16:29.130 --> 00:16:32.420
Or, maybe you did a basic,
you only have two gigs of storage.

335
00:16:32.420 --> 00:16:36.540
And your index is taking 400 megs
of that storage, that's a big deal.

336
00:16:36.540 --> 00:16:40.880
So we might need to defragment the indexes
to get them to take less storage.

337
00:16:40.880 --> 00:16:43.790
That's the most common in Azure,
but on magnetic media,

338
00:16:43.790 --> 00:16:46.020
you need to defragment them
to improve performance also.

339
00:16:47.040 --> 00:16:51.590
So as the indexes run,
over time you may need to defragment them.

340
00:16:51.590 --> 00:16:55.170
If you don't, in Azure they'll run just
fine because they're running on SSE.

341
00:16:55.170 --> 00:16:58.450
You could set it and forget it, but
it's going to start eating storage.

342
00:16:58.450 --> 00:17:01.629
The more data you delete then the more
storage it's going to consume.

343
00:17:01.629 --> 00:17:03.430
If you never delete anything,
if you just add,

344
00:17:03.430 --> 00:17:04.969
then it's really not that big of a deal.

345
00:17:04.969 --> 00:17:06.460
You can ignore it.

346
00:17:06.460 --> 00:17:08.520
But for most of us we need to go in and
defragment.

347
00:17:08.520 --> 00:17:11.430
Right now,
Microsoft has some simple rules.

348
00:17:11.430 --> 00:17:16.392
If the fragmentation is between 5 and
30, well if it's between 0 and 5%,

349
00:17:16.392 --> 00:17:19.590
don't do anything,
it's just 5%, who cares?

350
00:17:19.590 --> 00:17:21.781
Leave it.
If it's between 5 and 30%,

351
00:17:21.781 --> 00:17:24.340
you can do what's called a reorganize.

352
00:17:24.340 --> 00:17:26.950
Reorganize is like defragmenting
the hard drive on your computer.

353
00:17:26.950 --> 00:17:31.210
It starts moving the data around to put it
in a nice neat order where everything's in

354
00:17:31.210 --> 00:17:34.090
order stored right there on the drive,
ready for rapid access.

355
00:17:34.090 --> 00:17:35.990
That's a reorganize.

356
00:17:35.990 --> 00:17:38.347
And it's up to 30% fragmentation for that.

357
00:17:38.347 --> 00:17:43.147
Anything above 30% fragmentation,
Microsoft recommends you do a rebuild.

358
00:17:43.147 --> 00:17:46.391
And what a rebuild does is it
just throws the index away and

359
00:17:46.391 --> 00:17:48.260
it builds an all new one.

360
00:17:48.260 --> 00:17:52.840
If your fragmentation is over 30%, it's
actually faster to just build an all new

361
00:17:52.840 --> 00:17:57.250
index than it is to go and try and
reorganize the one you've got.

362
00:17:57.250 --> 00:18:00.570
And so that's just a cost to
benefit ratio type of thing.

363
00:18:00.570 --> 00:18:03.530
If it's over 30% fragmentation,
just rebuild it.

364
00:18:03.530 --> 00:18:05.230
And if we want to do that.

365
00:18:05.230 --> 00:18:07.540

Some of the options that you

00:18:21.520 --> 00:18:22.600

00:18:26.120 --> 00:18:32.140

00:18:49.090 --> 00:18:52.321
And when you run a local and

00:18:52.321 --> 00:18:56.300
you can just right-click on

And in the menu that comes up,

in there you'll have rebuild index,

00:19:05.830 --> 00:19:08.760
Now the reason I don't have it is

00:19:08.760 --> 00:19:09.940
that's not supported.

00:19:09.940 --> 00:19:11.430
So if you wanna rebuild or

00:19:14.980 --> 00:19:19.030
The reason it's not here is Microsoft is

00:20:09.610 --> 00:20:13.980

00:20:13.980 --> 00:20:17.600

00:20:17.600 --> 00:20:20.020

00:20:20.020 --> 00:20:23.060

00:20:23.060 --> 00:20:25.080
It's kind of a complex query.

00:20:33.390 --> 00:20:37.560
And so on MSDN, they have a slightly

00:20:37.560 --> 00:20:40.140
And so here we actually see a little

416
00:20:40.140 --> 00:20:43.920
It's pulling the index ID, the name and
the average fragmentation in

00:20:43.920 --> 00:20:47.355

00:20:47.355 --> 00:20:52.645
From my case, for example, DB1 for

419
00:20:52.645 --> 00:20:55.205
So just from that one table,

00:20:55.205 --> 00:20:56.935
And that's why this query's so

00:20:56.935 --> 00:20:59.854
It's not having to figure out all

00:20:59.854 --> 00:21:05.154
And when we run that query, which I've

1%?

I can ignore that, right?

00:21:25.700 --> 00:21:28.570

Product ProductNumber 50% fragmentation,

00:21:41.360 --> 00:21:45.080

00:21:45.080 --> 00:21:49.670

00:21:49.670 --> 00:21:53.972
and might be eating up a ton of space,

00:21:53.972 --> 00:21:57.403
At 33%, I'm right on that border,
right on that 30% border,

00:21:57.403 --> 00:22:00.670
where Microsoft says don't reorganize,
do a rebuild.

439
00:22:00.670 --> 00:22:03.750
And if I wanted to do that,
if I wanted to go ahead and rebuild it,

00:22:03.750 --> 00:22:08.615
then I would just need to punch in,
the command's actually pretty simple here.

441
00:22:08.615 --> 00:22:13.040
Oh, see, it has AKA product
name is what that's called.

00:22:13.040 --> 00:22:19.070
Let me fire up a new query here.

00:22:19.070 --> 00:22:23.844
The command to rebuild this is just, let
me zoom in a little bit so you guys will

00:22:23.844 --> 00:22:28.479

00:22:28.479 --> 00:22:32.663
I need to alter an index and mine, shoot,

00:22:32.663 --> 00:22:37.225
I've already forgotten what it was called.

Was it SalesLT.Product?

00:22:40.142 --> 00:22:44.270
All right, wait a minute, [LAUGH] I

00:22:44.270 --> 00:22:46.300
on my own screen,

00:22:48.110 --> 00:22:50.760
I know Daniel's over here trying to not

00:22:57.121 --> 00:23:00.499

00:23:00.499 --> 00:23:04.800
Here's the table,
here's the index that I want to modify.

00:23:04.800 --> 00:23:09.660
And then I just need to say REORGANIZE

00:23:09.660 --> 00:23:14.007
If I want to do an online
defragmentation if it's less than 30%,

458
00:23:14.007 --> 00:23:17.688
this will do it and
just kinda reorganize it and get done.

459
00:23:17.688 --> 00:23:22.760
But if it's beyond 30%, Microsoft's
recommendation is to do a rebuild.

00:23:22.760 --> 00:23:27.050
And you can do REBUILD like that, and

00:23:27.050 --> 00:23:30.250

create a new one.

462
00:23:30.250 --> 00:23:32.060
Quick word of advice on this.

463
00:23:32.060 --> 00:23:35.360
If this is just a small business, if you
just have a few users in the system,

00:23:35.360 --> 00:23:36.720
then REBUILD just like that, it's fine.

465
00:23:37.720 --> 00:23:42.658
But if this is a massive database where
you have hundreds or thousands of users in

466
00:23:42.658 --> 00:23:47.462
the database at all times when it drops
that index, you longer have an index.

467
00:23:47.462 --> 00:23:50.313
And it has to build a new one and
if it's a large data set,

468
00:23:50.313 --> 00:23:52.088
it could take a couple of minutes.

469
00:23:52.088 --> 00:23:55.212
And during that time,
people are running queries with no index.

470
00:23:55.212 --> 00:23:57.171
And performance is gonna be slow,
all right?

471
00:23:57.171 --> 00:24:00.065
You saw in the first episode
the difference in time it took for

472
00:24:00.065 --> 00:24:02.676

versus without an index,

473
00:24:02.676 --> 00:24:04.880
that's gonna happen to your users, right?

474
00:24:04.880 --> 00:24:08.610
So there's an extra option you can
tack onto the end of this, and

00:24:08.610 --> 00:24:10.990
Microsoft calls it an option,

00:24:10.990 --> 00:24:17.068
I kinda always do this one,
which is where we just say WITH,

00:24:17.068 --> 00:24:21.710

00:24:21.710 --> 00:24:24.037
Okay, it's a little extra option, okay?

00:24:24.037 --> 00:24:27.644
And what that option says is,

00:24:46.980 --> 00:24:50.720
So just make sure that it's an online

00:24:50.720 --> 00:24:52.870
now users are always running

488
00:24:52.870 --> 00:24:55.602
It may not be the greatest,
but at least it is an index.

489
00:24:55.602 --> 00:24:58.530
All right, and so
those are great ways that we can do that.

490
00:24:58.530 --> 00:25:00.242
Your DBA's, they know about this.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel talk about database maintenance tasks in Azure SQL. They begin with the demarcation of duties; what tasks are being handled by Microsoft(backups, replication, consistency checks) and what tasks are handled by the customer(index creation/maintenance, data partitioning, and statistics). Finally they take a close look at database statistics; specifically creating, maintaining, and removing statistics. Also covered is Asynchronous Statistics.

And so when I run that,

How dense are the results?

00:26:18.860 --> 00:26:20.750

00:26:24.590 --> 00:26:25.930

00:26:25.930 --> 00:26:30.290
So if I'm about to do an intensive query,

00:26:30.290 --> 00:26:33.710
a bulk change, I might wanna

00:26:33.710 --> 00:26:35.780
I don't wanna have to wait for

00:26:35.780 --> 00:26:37.640
Right, and so

00:26:37.640 --> 00:26:41.100

LastName_Firstname.

00:27:26.989 --> 00:27:30.002

by doing that you know,
you get the latest and

00:27:34.215 --> 00:27:36.806
So that's one way that
you can jump in there and

knock those out if you got AUTO_UPDATE

00:27:41.525 --> 00:27:46.245

then if you ever wanna see the statistics,

00:27:53.450 --> 00:27:56.239

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel show you how to keep a watchful eye on your Azure SQL deployment by utilizing monitoring services. They start by exploring the Database Health check and looking at database events in the Azure SQL portal. They then show you how to monitor your database size and setup alerts to warn you when an action needs to be taken. Lastly, they demonstrate the Dynamic Management Views(DMVs) which works querying the database for specific information in real time.

But when they do the whole one, right?

523
00:25:28.330 --> 00:25:31.080
So if you look down here
I've got another query

524
00:25:31.080 --> 00:25:35.710
that is SELECT*FROM Employees
WHERE LastName is LIKE 'S%'.

525
00:25:35.710 --> 00:25:38.880
Okay, now they're just getting a subset.

526
00:25:38.880 --> 00:25:40.320
And look at the difference.

527
00:25:40.320 --> 00:25:45.100
It was 16,604 for
CPU time for the whole table,

528
00:25:45.100 --> 00:25:49.520
versus only 3,835 for just getting
people's last name started with S.

529
00:25:49.520 --> 00:25:54.090
So, if I can get people to use
a more selective query, it actually

530
00:25:54.090 --> 00:25:58.030
alleviates the burden on the server and
it's mostly because of disc io right?

531
00:25:58.030 --> 00:26:01.420
Then when you're reading more data
up here than you were down here.

532
00:26:01.420 --> 00:26:03.110
So these are things that
we need to watch and

533
00:26:03.110 --> 00:26:07.450
again take action on to improve and the
dynamic management views let you see that.

534
00:26:07.450 --> 00:26:09.930
We can also see those
through other manners right?

535
00:26:09.930 --> 00:26:13.180
Through like the index
advisor in the query store.

536
00:26:13.180 --> 00:26:14.520
They're tracking this stuff, too.

537
00:26:14.520 --> 00:26:17.790
So a lot of this has a way to see this
from the GUI if you have access, but

538
00:26:17.790 --> 00:26:21.040
if you don't you can query it right
here through dynamic management views.

539
00:26:21.040 --> 00:26:22.340
Very powerful stuff.

540
00:26:22.340 --> 00:26:25.480
Check out Microsoft's tech net site,
they have wealth of information on there.

541
00:26:25.480 --> 00:26:29.500
There's literally thousands of
dynamic management views available.

542
00:26:29.500 --> 00:26:30.020
Tons of them.

543
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:32.050
You can query all sorts of data.

544
00:26:32.050 --> 00:26:34.480
You just have to know how, and
some of it's pretty complex.

545
00:26:34.480 --> 00:26:37.783
>> Well, Don, that's gonna help you out
a lot, cuz you're gonna look at that top

546
00:26:37.783 --> 00:26:41.160
query there, and it's gonna be me, and
you can come by and go, you are an idiot.

547
00:26:41.160 --> 00:26:44.595
Stop querying the entirety
of our database for stuff.

548
00:26:44.595 --> 00:26:45.620
Okay?
>> You gotta figure

549
00:26:45.620 --> 00:26:47.230
out which employee to terminate.

550
00:26:47.230 --> 00:26:47.900
>> That's right.

551
00:26:47.900 --> 00:26:49.435
Where do you not cut the check?

552
00:26:49.435 --> 00:26:51.210
[LAUGH]
>> Sometimes it's human resources

553
00:26:51.210 --> 00:26:52.670
optimization that solves the problem.

554
00:26:52.670 --> 00:26:53.820
>> That's right.

555
00:26:53.820 --> 00:26:55.382
>> Wealth of information, right?

556
00:26:55.382 --> 00:26:58.534
So, in the GUI we saw monitoring,
we saw the health check,

557
00:26:58.534 --> 00:27:00.120
we saw alerts and the events.

558
00:27:00.120 --> 00:27:02.149
Right?
All different ways we can see what's going

559
00:27:02.149 --> 00:27:05.196
on on our server in the SQL management
studio, just through transac SQL,

560
00:27:05.196 --> 00:27:08.950
we've got dynamic management views where
we can query tons of performance data.

561
00:27:08.950 --> 00:27:11.230
Between those features,

562
00:27:11.230 --> 00:27:15.060
you really do have full view of
the performance of your system.

563
00:27:15.060 --> 00:27:18.530
And we don't have to worry about
things like, can I ping the server,

564
00:27:18.530 --> 00:27:21.430
can I connect on that port,
because Microsoft's tracking that.

565
00:27:21.430 --> 00:27:24.030
I don't have to worry about,
are the hard drives gonna fail,

566
00:27:24.030 --> 00:27:27.020
are the redundant power supplies plugged
in, Microsoft takes care of that.

567
00:27:27.020 --> 00:27:28.040
I just care about performance.

568
00:27:28.040 --> 00:27:29.520
That's all I have to worry about.

569
00:27:29.520 --> 00:27:31.880
And I've got full visibility into that.

570
00:27:31.880 --> 00:27:35.390
So even though I've lost some of
the tools I've used for years and years.

571
00:27:35.390 --> 00:27:37.340
Right?
Some things like Sequel Profiler,

572
00:27:37.340 --> 00:27:39.560
I used it the first time 16 years ago.

573
00:27:39.560 --> 00:27:41.860
So I've used it a long time.

574
00:27:41.860 --> 00:27:46.140
It's gone now, but I don't really miss it,
because I don't need it in the same way

575
00:27:46.140 --> 00:27:49.150
that I needed it before when I was
dealing with on-premises servers.

576
00:27:49.150 --> 00:27:51.340
So the tools that we've got,
very powerful.

577
00:27:51.340 --> 00:27:54.180
And there's even more
on the developer side.

578
00:27:54.180 --> 00:27:58.580
There's APIs where you can hook into
Azure and get all sorts of crazy data and

579
00:27:58.580 --> 00:27:59.120
pull it there.

580
00:27:59.120 --> 00:28:03.705
Now if, let me throw this out there,
if you hate all this.

581
00:28:03.705 --> 00:28:08.670
So, you hate all that, you want that
full visibility, you want that control.

582
00:28:08.670 --> 00:28:15.830
Well, the other option is don't use Azure
SQL, instead use Azure Virtual Machines.

583
00:28:15.830 --> 00:28:20.860
Spin up an Azure VM with SQL installed,
Microsoft's got them, and now you'll

584
00:28:20.860 --> 00:28:25.560
have access to the underlying operating
system as well as the SQL install itself.

585
00:28:25.560 --> 00:28:28.380
And you'll have all the old tools
that you're used to, you'll

586
00:28:28.380 --> 00:28:32.750
have the Windows performance monitor, the
SQL profiler, all those things are there.

587
00:28:32.750 --> 00:28:35.540
The database engine tuning advisor,
it's all there,

588
00:28:35.540 --> 00:28:39.680
the trade off is you've now taken
full control of that SQL install.

589
00:28:39.680 --> 00:28:41.590
Microsoft's not backing it up for you.

590
00:28:41.590 --> 00:28:43.920
They're not doing restores
when a failure happens.

591
00:28:43.920 --> 00:28:46.550
They're not setting up
automated email alerts for you.

592
00:28:46.550 --> 00:28:48.230
You've gotta do all that on your own.

593
00:28:48.230 --> 00:28:50.670
But if you want that control,
it's still there and

594
00:28:50.670 --> 00:28:52.870
now you just manage the server
like it's an on premises server.

595
00:28:52.870 --> 00:28:56.130
So you've got that functionality,
that choice is there for you to make.

596
00:28:56.130 --> 00:28:58.324
>> Awesome, Don,
this has been a fascinating episode of.

597
00:28:58.324 --> 00:29:02.750
I've thoroughly enjoyed learning about
this, cuz if you're a DB noob like myself,

598
00:29:02.750 --> 00:29:04.820
this stuff starts to really help you out.

599
00:29:04.820 --> 00:29:07.660
Cuz every now and then we do
have to do some SQL querying and

600
00:29:07.660 --> 00:29:09.190
it can be burdensome.

601
00:29:09.190 --> 00:29:12.205
And if we're going into the cloud to
mess with Azure, and start doing that.

602
00:29:12.205 --> 00:29:17.200
Well, having a full knowledge or
at least an understanding of the options

603
00:29:17.200 --> 00:29:20.360
laid before you so Don thanks so
much for this episode.

604
00:29:20.360 --> 00:29:22.790
Hopefully our viewers out there
got a lot from this as well.

605
00:29:22.790 --> 00:29:25.705
That being said we have exhausted
our time for this show.

606
00:29:25.705 --> 00:29:27.005
We're gonna go ahead and close her down.

607
00:29:27.005 --> 00:29:30.045
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

608
00:29:30.045 --> 00:29:30.885
>> And I'm Don Pazet.

609
00:29:30.885 --> 00:29:31.865
>> And we'll see you next time.

610
00:29:31.865 --> 00:29:37.490
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the concept and practice of scaling a Azure SQL database. Here they are going to show you how to scale your databases up or down, which can save costs, depending on your need. They also talk about scaling automation, which can help you scale your environment up and/or down at times when you know performance needs are going to change.
episodes.title: Scaling Up/Down
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.217 --> 00:00:15.920
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.920 --> 00:00:18.900
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:22.570
we're gonna continue taking
a look at Microsoft Azure SQL.

5
00:00:22.570 --> 00:00:26.560
And joining us today in the studio is
our resident expert on said topic and

6
00:00:26.560 --> 00:00:29.160
that is none other than Mr.
Don Pezet himself.

7
00:00:29.160 --> 00:00:30.950
Don, welcome to the show,
how are you doing today sir?

8
00:00:30.950 --> 00:00:33.240
>> I'm doing great Daniel, thanks for
having me back on the show and

9
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:34.620
today we're gonna be tackling a new topic.

10
00:00:34.620 --> 00:00:39.180
We're gonna take a look at scaling
our database instances up and down.

11
00:00:39.180 --> 00:00:42.629
Right, when we build up a database
instance, we have to pick a performance

12
00:00:42.629 --> 00:00:45.280
tier for it and
that performance tier is not set in stone.

13
00:00:45.280 --> 00:00:50.370
You can change it after the fact and
it really is a neat way to kind of

14
00:00:50.370 --> 00:00:54.360
upgrade your system and do it online
without taking the database offline.

15
00:00:54.360 --> 00:00:57.470
It's one of the best features of
having your database up in Azure SQL.

16
00:00:57.470 --> 00:00:59.430
So we wanna see how to do that,
how it works and

17
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:00.560
kind of walk through that process.

18
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:02.330
>> Yeah, that sounds really cool,
Don, and I'm guessin,

19
00:01:02.330 --> 00:01:05.360
the first thing that comes to my mind
when we start talking about scaling

20
00:01:05.360 --> 00:01:07.880
is what are some of the reasons
that I would do that.

21
00:01:07.880 --> 00:01:12.470
If I'm new to Azure SQL and
I'm thinking maybe I need to do this.

22
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:15.820
What are the main reasons you
would see this happening?

23
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:17.350
>> So, there's several reasons.

24
00:01:17.350 --> 00:01:19.750
The most obvious one that comes to
mind is you pick the wrong tier.

25
00:01:19.750 --> 00:01:22.620
Right, it does happen and
then you've got to just go and correct it.

26
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:24.850
But there's plenty of other reasons,
right?

27
00:01:24.850 --> 00:01:27.850
Typically when we deploy
a database into Azure SQL,

28
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:30.570
the thing we have to remember and I know
I've mentioned this in other episodes.

29
00:01:30.570 --> 00:01:34.060
Is that unlike Azure VM,
where when you spin up a VM,

30
00:01:34.060 --> 00:01:35.428
if you're not gonna use it for a while.

31
00:01:35.428 --> 00:01:38.800
You can just shut it down and
you only pay for storage, with Azure SQL,

32
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:41.150
when you spin up a database,
it's always up.

33
00:01:41.150 --> 00:01:42.600
You're always paying for it.

34
00:01:42.600 --> 00:01:44.670
Whether you use it or not,
you're always paying for it and

35
00:01:44.670 --> 00:01:46.630
there's no way to just shut it down and
suspend it.

36
00:01:46.630 --> 00:01:48.140
You have to delete it, right?

37
00:01:48.140 --> 00:01:51.420
So what if I'm bringing up something for
test and development.

38
00:01:51.420 --> 00:01:53.590
Or doing like what I do
here in the show and

39
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:55.608
I just need a database to
show you guys an example.

40
00:01:55.608 --> 00:01:58.920
I don't wanna pay a ton of money for it,
I just wanna whip up a simple database and

41
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:00.020
get it up and running.

42
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:03.725
We could pick a low tier, one of
the lower performance levels to do that.

43
00:02:03.725 --> 00:02:08.680
And then, when we're ready to move it
into production, we're done with testing,

44
00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:10.615
we had five users in there yesterday.

45
00:02:10.615 --> 00:02:13.220
Tomorrow we're gonna have
5,000 users in there.

46
00:02:13.220 --> 00:02:16.680
So let's go ahead and
bump it up to a higher tier, so

47
00:02:16.680 --> 00:02:20.090
now it's got the higher DTUs to
be able to handle that load.

48
00:02:20.090 --> 00:02:23.289
That is a big feature here for
us to be able to do that.

49
00:02:23.289 --> 00:02:26.258
So when you go from testing
to actual production,

50
00:02:26.258 --> 00:02:30.440
you bump up to the higher tier and
now you pay for the resources you use.

51
00:02:31.440 --> 00:02:34.390
On the same side,
maybe it's already in production,

52
00:02:34.390 --> 00:02:38.780
maybe I rolled out this database and at
this time last year, it was running fine.

53
00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:42.410
But my company's been doing great,
the database has been getting bigger and

54
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:44.440
I've got a lot more
users that are in there.

55
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:47.860
And so I might wanna bump up
to a new performance tier

56
00:02:47.860 --> 00:02:49.910
just to handle the increased
load that I've got.

57
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:51.315
And when I say increased load,

58
00:02:51.315 --> 00:02:53.960
we gotta think about the different
characteristics of each tier, right?

59
00:02:53.960 --> 00:02:57.160
When you spin up an instance and
you pick the basic tier or

60
00:02:57.160 --> 00:02:59.220
the standard tier or whatever.

61
00:02:59.220 --> 00:03:02.180
Each tier has different
resources available to it and

62
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:03.730
you can run out of those resources.

63
00:03:03.730 --> 00:03:06.650
I'll bring up Microsoft's
page here on the tiers.

64
00:03:06.650 --> 00:03:08.634
But the tears,
the sadness of a SQL database.

65
00:03:08.634 --> 00:03:11.484
>> [LAUGH]
>> So this is Microsoft's article on

66
00:03:11.484 --> 00:03:17.210
the Azure Documentation site, where they
run down the service tiers of Azure SQL.

67
00:03:17.210 --> 00:03:19.200
And as you look at this,

68
00:03:19.200 --> 00:03:22.100
what you'll see is some of
the things that we've talked about.

69
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:23.460
We've really focused on DTUs.

70
00:03:23.460 --> 00:03:27.190
That's the one that I always talk about,
those database throughput units.

71
00:03:27.190 --> 00:03:30.410
And you'll see it like the basic tier,
you've only got 5 DTUs.

72
00:03:30.410 --> 00:03:35.390
But as you start moving up into
Standard and Premium, you get 10, 20,

73
00:03:35.390 --> 00:03:39.650
50, 100 DTUs,
all the way up to 1,750 DTUs.

74
00:03:39.650 --> 00:03:41.670
So if I'm monitoring my server and

75
00:03:41.670 --> 00:03:45.010
I'm seeing that the amount of
queries that I'm pushing and so on.

76
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:48.210
Is just starting to
really hit too hard and

77
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:51.340
my server can't keep up with it and
people are getting throttled.

78
00:03:51.340 --> 00:03:53.980
Then I need to bump up to
the next year to get more DTUs.

79
00:03:53.980 --> 00:03:57.070
And I showed you guys way back in the,

80
00:03:57.070 --> 00:03:58.890
was it the creating your
first database episode?

81
00:03:58.890 --> 00:04:02.620
It was one of the early episodes, where I
showed you guys how you can monitor for

82
00:04:02.620 --> 00:04:04.430
any of the queuing that happens.

83
00:04:04.430 --> 00:04:06.366
To let you know that hey,
you're being throttled,

84
00:04:06.366 --> 00:04:08.220
there's that throttling error metric.

85
00:04:08.220 --> 00:04:11.740
Then if you start to see a hit,
that means you're running out of DTUs.

86
00:04:11.740 --> 00:04:13.930
But that's not the only
thing you can run out of.

87
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:17.870
Notice that each database size
has a maximum database size.

88
00:04:17.870 --> 00:04:21.560
If I spin up a Basic for testing,
I can leave 2 gigs of data.

89
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:24.815
My production data might exceed that
really fast, so I might go to a Standard.

90
00:04:24.815 --> 00:04:29.830
Now at a Standard,
I might be only needing 10 DTUs.

91
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:33.800
But if I've got more than 250 gigs of
data, it doesn't matter that I've got S1,

92
00:04:33.800 --> 00:04:37.240
S2 and S3,
they're all limited to 250 gigs.

93
00:04:37.240 --> 00:04:38.520
If I need more storage,

94
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:43.030
I'm gonna have to bump up to a P1
even though I only need 10 DTUs.

95
00:04:43.030 --> 00:04:46.980
So DTUs aren't the only reason
why we might need to upgrade

96
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:48.960
if we just need more storage.

97
00:04:48.960 --> 00:04:50.880
We might have to bump up to a Premium or

98
00:04:50.880 --> 00:04:54.002
even all the way up to a P11
if the database is big enough.

99
00:04:54.002 --> 00:04:56.480
It's kind of sad in a way,

100
00:04:56.480 --> 00:05:01.330
that you might have just something
that needs 10 DTUs of access.

101
00:05:01.330 --> 00:05:02.560
But because it's a terabyte in size,

102
00:05:02.560 --> 00:05:04.450
you gotta go all they way
up to a P11 to handle it.

103
00:05:04.450 --> 00:05:06.486
And so there's other techniques for
handling that if you need to.

104
00:05:06.486 --> 00:05:10.860
I'm gonna talk about scaling up and
scaling down in this episode.

105
00:05:10.860 --> 00:05:12.285
But you can also do what's
called scaling out.

106
00:05:12.285 --> 00:05:15.391
And with scaling out, I could say boy,

107
00:05:15.391 --> 00:05:20.800
I need a terabyte of database space,
but I only need ten DTUs.

108
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:22.350
And I don't wanna go up to a P11.

109
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:27.220
I think we saw earlier that if I do an S0,
right, so that very base one,

110
00:05:27.220 --> 00:05:30.320
I think an S0 cost about $15 a month.

111
00:05:30.320 --> 00:05:33.820
First is a P11,
they cost about $7,000 a month.

112
00:05:33.820 --> 00:05:37.600
Right, that's a huge difference and
it's because of the increased DTUs.

113
00:05:37.600 --> 00:05:38.995
So if I wanted to scale out,

114
00:05:38.995 --> 00:05:41.866
what I could do is say I need
a terrabyte of data, right?

115
00:05:41.866 --> 00:05:48.314
So I could spin up four S0s and
I can do what's called database sharding,

116
00:05:48.314 --> 00:05:52.240
I can shard my database into four pieces.

117
00:05:52.240 --> 00:05:57.650
So I had 250 gigs in one S0 instance,
another 250 gigs in another S0.

118
00:05:57.650 --> 00:06:02.590
And I could have four of this S0s,
each holding 250 gigs of data.

119
00:06:02.590 --> 00:06:05.650
And I could have a shard controller
that when I did a look up

120
00:06:05.650 --> 00:06:09.650
would map to all four of those and
I'd be able to see that information.

121
00:06:09.650 --> 00:06:13.440
And that gets it to where I can
have a terabyte of storage and

122
00:06:13.440 --> 00:06:15.620
only 10 DTUs for each of those elements.

123
00:06:15.620 --> 00:06:17.790
I end up with basically 40 DTUs.

124
00:06:17.790 --> 00:06:20.476
So now it's costing me,
if each one's $15 a month,

125
00:06:20.476 --> 00:06:23.752
you end up with $60 a month
versus $7,000 a month, right?

126
00:06:24.810 --> 00:06:27.030
Now I'm not gonna tackle
sharding in this series,

127
00:06:27.030 --> 00:06:29.480
probably not,
I guess I might if I get really bored.

128
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:32.080
But probably not because it's not
something that we as system admins have to

129
00:06:32.080 --> 00:06:33.670
deal with, it's the developers.

130
00:06:33.670 --> 00:06:35.542
Right, the developers when they
write their queries and stuff,

131
00:06:35.542 --> 00:06:37.943
they have to make it where they know how
to reach across these different databases.

132
00:06:37.943 --> 00:06:40.500

Then I can't downscale to a basic.

353
00:18:01.050 --> 00:18:03.580
You can up scale to any tier, but

354
00:18:03.580 --> 00:18:07.750
you can only down scale to tiers that
have enough resources available to

355
00:18:07.750 --> 00:18:12.000
support your database, so if your database
has more than two gigs of storage,

356
00:18:12.000 --> 00:18:15.950
you can't down scale to a basic until
you get that database sized down.

357
00:18:15.950 --> 00:18:19.900
You've got to start clearing down data,
you know removing tables.

358
00:18:19.900 --> 00:18:23.910
Or instead of down-scaling,
spin up a new instance, right,

359
00:18:23.910 --> 00:18:27.450
that has the smaller data set, but
otherwise you won't be able to downscale.

360
00:18:27.450 --> 00:18:31.190
So there are times where you can't
downscale, you can always upscale,

361
00:18:31.190 --> 00:18:35.370
but there is times we can't downscale and
storage is the big one, right?

362
00:18:35.370 --> 00:18:38.460
Some of these other features
though may be I had it as a P1 and

00:18:38.460 --> 00:18:41.390
I was doing Active Geo-Replication.

00:18:41.390 --> 00:18:45.190
If I downscale that down to a basic,

00:18:45.190 --> 00:18:48.790
It's going to disable replication and it's
going to delete the secondary servers,

366
00:18:48.790 --> 00:18:50.850
because we can't replicate to them.

367
00:18:50.850 --> 00:18:53.190
Well, it doesn't actually
delete the secondary servers.

368
00:18:53.190 --> 00:18:55.590
What it does is it breaks it apart
as its own standalone server.

369
00:18:55.590 --> 00:19:00.060
And so now I've got my primary as
a basic and this backup is still up and

370
00:19:00.060 --> 00:19:02.890
running as a P1 or whatever,
and so you got a cost there.

371
00:19:02.890 --> 00:19:04.545
So you've got to be on the lookout for
that.

372
00:19:04.545 --> 00:19:07.540
Down-scaling's a little more
sensitive because of that.

373
00:19:07.540 --> 00:19:11.690
If I was just scaling for DTUs and
that was it, then it's not a big deal.

374
00:19:11.690 --> 00:19:14.780
You can go upscale, downscale,
do at your heart's content.

375
00:19:14.780 --> 00:19:18.780
But if you did it in storage or
replication or backup Windows,

376
00:19:18.780 --> 00:19:21.390
if all that was involved,
then we've got to be careful.

377
00:19:21.390 --> 00:19:24.020
I'm glad I said back up Windows,
because if I was at a P1,

378
00:19:24.020 --> 00:19:27.160
I could have 35 days of retention.

379
00:19:27.160 --> 00:19:32.520
The instant I go down to a basic,
it deletes day eight through 35.

380
00:19:32.520 --> 00:19:35.760
So, if I down scaled to a basic for
five minutes and

381
00:19:35.760 --> 00:19:41.020
then upscaled back to a P1 again, I just
lost 20 some odd days of backups, right?

382
00:19:41.020 --> 00:19:42.740
And I can't get those back.

383
00:19:42.740 --> 00:19:44.220
So again, we've got to be careful.

384
00:19:44.220 --> 00:19:46.110
Downscaling is just a little more risky,

385
00:19:46.110 --> 00:19:48.810
the steps for
doing it are the same, right?

386
00:19:48.810 --> 00:19:51.120
We just go to that pricing tier and
we change it.

387
00:19:51.120 --> 00:19:54.270
In fact mine should be done at this point,
let's see if we're done.

00:19:54.270 --> 00:19:57.080
And let's see, oh it's not refreshed.

00:19:57.080 --> 00:19:58.420
Let's go back here.

00:19:58.420 --> 00:19:59.130
We'll refresh this.
