00:19:59.130 --> 00:20:02.470
You know your UI doesn't
always refresh right away.

392
00:20:02.470 --> 00:20:03.460
There we go.

393
00:20:03.460 --> 00:20:06.850
So I can see that my pricing
tier is now Basic 5 DTUs.

394
00:20:06.850 --> 00:20:08.490
So no big deal down scaling.

395
00:20:08.490 --> 00:20:09.940
We just need to be aware of those caveats,
right,

396
00:20:09.940 --> 00:20:12.670
the things that can kind of catch us and
make this not work.

397
00:20:12.670 --> 00:20:16.040
>> Awesome, now Don, obviously,
if we need to upscale,

398
00:20:16.040 --> 00:20:18.880
we're watching the performance of our
servers, we're watching how much money

399
00:20:18.880 --> 00:20:23.760
we're spending, and usually, it seems
to me anyway, that a lot of times,

400
00:20:23.760 --> 00:20:26.770
especially when it comes to a database,
they have their peaks and valleys.

401
00:20:26.770 --> 00:20:29.350
They have times when we
need performance and

402
00:20:29.350 --> 00:20:31.850
then there's times when we
don't need performance.

403
00:20:31.850 --> 00:20:36.740
As an admin, am I just going to have to
monitor this and adjust accordingly or

404
00:20:36.740 --> 00:20:38.705
is there any way we can
automate that process?

405
00:20:38.705 --> 00:20:40.640
Because I'm all about automation.

406
00:20:40.640 --> 00:20:44.260
>> All right this one's kind of a sticky,
it's a sticky question right so

407
00:20:44.260 --> 00:20:47.770
when we have things like web servers,
you can auto scale them.

408
00:20:47.770 --> 00:20:50.400
You can say all right this server's
getting really busy let's spin up some

409
00:20:50.400 --> 00:20:55.300
more clones, let's do a load balancer
across it and then start growing it and

410
00:20:55.300 --> 00:20:58.480
it works great, and you can scale out
to hundreds or thousands of servers and

411
00:20:58.480 --> 00:21:00.170
really get some great performance.

412
00:21:00.170 --> 00:21:01.990
But databases aren't like that.

413
00:21:01.990 --> 00:21:06.320
Because what you don't want
is two people writing to

414
00:21:06.320 --> 00:21:08.530
two different databases at the same time.

415
00:21:08.530 --> 00:21:10.220
And then those records conflict.

416
00:21:10.220 --> 00:21:12.780
Right?
You can't have conflicting records in

417
00:21:12.780 --> 00:21:13.640
a database.

418
00:21:13.640 --> 00:21:17.770
So you always need to be able
to write to a single master.

419
00:21:17.770 --> 00:21:19.370
You can read from any number of services.

420
00:21:19.370 --> 00:21:20.280
You have read replicas.

421
00:21:20.280 --> 00:21:21.550
People do that all the time, right.

422
00:21:21.550 --> 00:21:24.190
And you can spin up read
replicas as you need them.

423
00:21:24.190 --> 00:21:29.650
But as far as writes, your writes really
need to go through a single server.

424
00:21:29.650 --> 00:21:34.460
And so if you want to scale up, you really
just have to monitor that single server.

425
00:21:34.460 --> 00:21:37.020
There's not automatic spinning
up of another one, but

426
00:21:37.020 --> 00:21:40.680
we can do things like automate
doing a scale change like this.

427
00:21:40.680 --> 00:21:45.470
So maybe I know, come December,
things are going to get busy.

428
00:21:45.470 --> 00:21:49.270
You can use what's called Azure
Automation, and you can write a script

429
00:21:49.270 --> 00:21:55.330
that says take this instance right here
and bump it up to a P1 on December 1st.

430
00:21:55.330 --> 00:21:59.530
And then you can have it run again on
January 1st to move it back to an S2, or

431
00:21:59.530 --> 00:22:00.450
whatever, right?

432
00:22:00.450 --> 00:22:03.450
So you can automate that process just so
you don't forget.

433
00:22:03.450 --> 00:22:05.910
But you can't really
key it to performance.

434
00:22:05.910 --> 00:22:09.000
You can't say, watch if the server's
getting busy, and if it gets busy,

435
00:22:09.000 --> 00:22:10.580
start spinning it up, right?

436
00:22:10.580 --> 00:22:12.080
Well, I shouldn't say you can't.

437
00:22:12.080 --> 00:22:12.610
You can do that.

438
00:22:12.610 --> 00:22:16.570
You can write trigger-based metrics that
watch for a metric to hit a certain value,

439
00:22:16.570 --> 00:22:17.450
and then executes a command.

440
00:22:17.450 --> 00:22:19.490
You can do all that
through Azure Automation.

441
00:22:19.490 --> 00:22:20.910
But, here's the problem.

442
00:22:20.910 --> 00:22:27.190
Microsoft limits scaling events on
a SQL database to four every 24 hours.

443
00:22:27.190 --> 00:22:29.330
So, take SampleDB2 here.

444
00:22:29.330 --> 00:22:31.299
I've already burned up two of my scales,
right?

445
00:22:31.299 --> 00:22:36.579
I took me from an S0 to an S1,
>> One.

446
00:22:36.579 --> 00:22:37.139
>> Right, okay?

447
00:22:37.139 --> 00:22:38.650
I'm already losing track of this.

448
00:22:38.650 --> 00:22:40.930
Then I went from an S1 down to a basic.

449
00:22:40.930 --> 00:22:43.270
So, if I go in to this one and
do another tier change,

450
00:22:43.270 --> 00:22:48.340
and I move it back to an S0,
so I go ahead and do that.

451
00:22:48.340 --> 00:22:51.540
When I put that change in,
there went my third one.

452
00:22:51.540 --> 00:22:54.368
And if I do one more,
it's now stuck for 24 hours,

453
00:22:54.368 --> 00:22:56.950
I've got to wait until
tomorrow to do anymore.

454
00:22:56.950 --> 00:23:00.325
So, if I'm trying to monitor
in real time like okay,

455
00:23:00.325 --> 00:23:05.140
server gets busy at five PM, slows down
at six PM, I can't react like that.

456
00:23:05.140 --> 00:23:08.520
Reacting on days, yes.

457
00:23:08.520 --> 00:23:12.600
Reacting on hours or minutes, not really,
unless you can hold it to four

458
00:23:12.600 --> 00:23:15.820
changes per day, and that makes
automating it really, really hard.

459
00:23:15.820 --> 00:23:18.950
So we normally see companies doing
this based around things like months,

460
00:23:18.950 --> 00:23:22.480
where they say all right,
December is a high sales month.

461
00:23:22.480 --> 00:23:24.480
We're going to scale up our database.

462
00:23:24.480 --> 00:23:28.480
Or maybe you're a tax company and so here
in the United States our taxes are due in

463
00:23:28.480 --> 00:23:33.400
April 15th, so you say in March and
April, we spin up our databases

464
00:23:33.400 --> 00:23:38.290
to handle more connections, and then come
May we just scale it back down again.

465
00:23:38.290 --> 00:23:41.800
So those are done on a month and
you could automate that pretty easily and

466
00:23:41.800 --> 00:23:43.210
that would knock it out or

467
00:23:43.210 --> 00:23:45.800
you could just do it by hand,
because it's not such a precise thing,

468
00:23:45.800 --> 00:23:49.890
but when you do things by hand that means
that there's an opportunity to forget, and

469
00:23:49.890 --> 00:23:54.580
so automating helps out so we're going
to do an episode on Azure automation.

470
00:23:54.580 --> 00:23:56.700
Because Azure automation it
doesn't just apply to Siclure,

471
00:23:56.700 --> 00:24:00.240
it applies to all of Azure and
you can automate all sorts of things but

472
00:24:00.240 --> 00:24:03.560
I want to show here, because it takes a
few steps to get it setup, authentication

473
00:24:03.560 --> 00:24:06.210
is kind of a trick with that so
we got a few things to worry about there.

474
00:24:06.210 --> 00:24:07.500
But I'll show you how to do it and

475
00:24:07.500 --> 00:24:10.340
we'll do like a scale up,
scale down with automation there.

476
00:24:10.340 --> 00:24:13.370
But just remember,
four scaling events per day,

477
00:24:13.370 --> 00:24:15.110
that's your limit,
big key thing to remember.

478
00:24:15.110 --> 00:24:18.330
>> Awesome, well Don is there anything
else that we need to know about scaling

479
00:24:18.330 --> 00:24:19.610
when it comes to Azure SQL?

480
00:24:20.650 --> 00:24:23.770
>> That's basically it,
do be aware that Microsoft does add

481
00:24:23.770 --> 00:24:26.850
new tiers all the time and
sometimes they remove tiers.

482
00:24:26.850 --> 00:24:31.630
Now that's important, for example,
if I go here into my pricing tiers and

483
00:24:31.630 --> 00:24:33.340
I look at what's available.

484
00:24:33.340 --> 00:24:35.540
It's going to give me a warning
because an update is in progress.

485
00:24:35.540 --> 00:24:40.530
But if we look at the available tiers
see how I've got P one, P two, P four.

00:24:40.530 --> 00:24:42.380
Where did P three go?

00:24:42.380 --> 00:24:46.710
Right there did used to be a P three,
it was there and it's gone.

00:24:46.710 --> 00:24:53.670
And then we've got P six and P eleven, and
P three was actually replaced by P three.

00:24:53.670 --> 00:24:59.300
So if you're on an older tier that
doesn't exist anymore, you've got it,

00:24:59.300 --> 00:25:03.760
it'll still run it whatever that tier was,
but if you upscale or downscale to

491
00:25:03.760 --> 00:25:07.080
something else, you won't be able to
return to that tier that's now gone.

492
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:08.140
All right?

493
00:25:08.140 --> 00:25:11.770
So be aware of,
did my request just finish, oh it did.

494
00:25:11.770 --> 00:25:12.390
Yep.
So

495
00:25:12.390 --> 00:25:16.280
just be aware if If you're on an old
tier that's gone, that's fine.

496
00:25:16.280 --> 00:25:17.310
You can stay on that tier forever.

497
00:25:17.310 --> 00:25:19.860
Microsoft won't kick you out, or
at least they haven't done it yet.

498
00:25:19.860 --> 00:25:21.970
But if you move away from it
you won't be able to come back.

499
00:25:21.970 --> 00:25:23.970
And that's not normally a big deal.

500
00:25:23.970 --> 00:25:25.870
If your tier's been replaced,

501
00:25:25.870 --> 00:25:29.800
that usually means there's a new tier

00:25:29.800 --> 00:25:35.320
And sometimes Microsoft will just update

00:25:35.320 --> 00:25:38.330
The basic one used to only be one DTU.

00:25:38.330 --> 00:25:43.740
And when they updated it, they updated

00:25:43.740 --> 00:25:46.690
But it was still just the basic tier,
so it just all of a sudden updated and

00:25:46.690 --> 00:25:47.710
that was that.

507
00:25:47.710 --> 00:25:51.630
But sometimes they replace a tier,
like the p3 that went away and

508
00:25:51.630 --> 00:25:53.930
you just won't be able to return to it,
so just be aware of that.

509
00:25:53.930 --> 00:25:58.560
>> Alright, well Don, thanks for showing
us how to optimize our performance and

00:25:58.560 --> 00:26:00.040
even maybe some money.

00:26:00.040 --> 00:26:04.930
Saving a little dough-re-me by using this
scaling up and down techniques in Azure.

00:26:04.930 --> 00:26:08.290

today.

00:26:08.290 --> 00:26:11.220
Well everyone out there, we have

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel dive into availability and recovery features provided by Azure SQL, here specifically looking at Geographical Redundancy. They start off by describing what geo-redundancy is and they two different types of geo-replication (Standard and Active) that's available in Azure SQL. Then they show you how to implement both types and even how to perform a failover test to make sure everything is working in case of an outage.

But it doesn't matter how

You don't pay a single dime extra, it's
just another system that's out there, and

00:01:24.630 --> 00:01:26.350
it's just super easy to take advantage of.

27
00:01:26.350 --> 00:01:28.350
So that's what we're gonna take

How we do geo-replication so that we can

00:01:32.470 --> 00:01:34.370

00:01:38.703 --> 00:01:40.961

how we can use it to our advantage.

00:01:40.961 --> 00:01:45.856
But the first question that pops into my
mind is, is this like a replacement for

00:01:45.856 --> 00:01:47.421
standard type backups?

>> I'm glad you asked that,

00:01:50.254 --> 00:01:51.313

redundancy thing that we have?

717
00:35:43.200 --> 00:35:46.737
>> So the key takeaway is, if you forget
everything else from the episode, right,

718
00:35:46.737 --> 00:35:48.570
is remember it's not on by default.

719
00:35:48.570 --> 00:35:51.270
You've gotta turn it on, right,
so that's kinda step one.

720
00:35:51.270 --> 00:35:54.390
You can use the elastic pools to try and

721
00:35:54.390 --> 00:35:56.410
reduce the cost of having
that backup if you want.

722
00:35:56.410 --> 00:35:58.160
That works great with standards, not so

723
00:35:58.160 --> 00:36:02.717
great with primaries because you've got
the readable copy, or premiums, sorry.

724
00:36:02.717 --> 00:36:07.130
And then the third thing is,
once it's on, Failover's really easy,

725
00:36:07.130 --> 00:36:08.580
Failover's pretty automatic.

726
00:36:08.580 --> 00:36:10.190
But your developers need
to be aware of this,

727
00:36:10.190 --> 00:36:11.760
because the server name actually changes.

728
00:36:11.760 --> 00:36:13.920
It's not the same server
name on the other side.

729
00:36:13.920 --> 00:36:15.750
So the application has
to be aware of this.

730
00:36:15.750 --> 00:36:18.067
The database is there,
it's active, it's ready to go,

731
00:36:18.067 --> 00:36:19.401
but it's on a different server.

732
00:36:19.401 --> 00:36:22.490
So, SQL Native Client has
that all built into it.

733
00:36:22.490 --> 00:36:25.279
Your developers will know to do that, you
just need to make sure they know about it.

734
00:36:25.279 --> 00:36:25.795
>> Awesome stuff.

735
00:36:25.795 --> 00:36:26.720
>> That's basically it.

736
00:36:26.720 --> 00:36:30.005
>> Well, Don, thank you so much for
helping us demystify some of this

737
00:36:30.005 --> 00:36:34.620
geo-replication, all this other goodness
that Azure has available for us.

738
00:36:34.620 --> 00:36:38.580
It is our benefit to learn how to
operate this thing, obviously,

739
00:36:38.580 --> 00:36:40.886
in case something awry goes, right?

740
00:36:40.886 --> 00:36:42.668
>> [LAUGH]
>> That being said, Don,

741
00:36:42.668 --> 00:36:45.042
it looks like our time
allotted has expired.

742
00:36:45.042 --> 00:36:47.650
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off right now for ITProTV,

743
00:36:47.650 --> 00:36:49.343
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

744
00:36:49.343 --> 00:36:50.238
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

745
00:36:50.238 --> 00:36:51.803
>> And we'll see you next time.

746
00:36:51.803 --> 00:36:58.320
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain how to recover data from a backup in case of an accidental deletion or corruption of data by implementing a self-service restore. They explain how Azure SQL takes backups and replicates data and then move into performing a restore from the Azure SQL portal as well as by using the PowerShell.
episodes.title: Self-Service Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.129 --> 00:00:16.291
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.291 --> 00:00:19.504
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.504 --> 00:00:22.089
we are continuing on with
our Azure SQL series.

5
00:00:22.089 --> 00:00:24.771
Joining me again in the studio today,
well, you know who it is,

6
00:00:24.771 --> 00:00:26.422
it's my good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:26.422 --> 00:00:27.422
Don, welcome back to the show.

8
00:00:27.422 --> 00:00:28.580
How you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:29.400
>> I am doing great.

10
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:32.840
Ready to jump right back into
the world of Azure SQL, and today

11
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:37.850
we're gonna do kind of a follow-up to, we
talked about backups and geo-replication,

12
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:41.490
and all these different things that
kind of keep our database nice and safe.

13
00:00:41.490 --> 00:00:43.970
Now we're gonna take a look
at doing a data restore,

14
00:00:43.970 --> 00:00:47.190
which is something we do when our
data turned out not to be so safe.

15
00:00:47.190 --> 00:00:49.193
So it's an important thing to understand,

16
00:00:49.193 --> 00:00:52.547
is that Azure SQL has a lot of great
technologies in there for backing up and

17
00:00:52.547 --> 00:00:55.901
protecting your data, but occasionally
you are gonna need to reach in and

18
00:00:55.901 --> 00:00:59.171
do a restore to be able to retrieve
that data, and get back in business.

19
00:00:59.171 --> 00:01:00.629
So that's what we've got on the plate.

20
00:01:00.629 --> 00:01:02.629
>> Yeah, unfortunately,
it's just a matter of fact.

21
00:01:02.629 --> 00:01:03.580
Things are gonna go awry.

22
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:06.944
They're gonna go bad, and when that
happens, we've gotta be schooled up,

23
00:01:06.944 --> 00:01:10.380
we've gotta know what to do, how we reach
into Azure and say help me, please.

24
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:14.000
I gotta get that data back, and Don,
that's what you're gonna show us today,

25
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:17.620
and you're gonna give us a little bit of
information to go along with that to help

26
00:01:17.620 --> 00:01:21.239
us better plan for those restores, make
sure we're doing it the right way, and

27
00:01:21.239 --> 00:01:22.671
following proper procedure.

28
00:01:22.671 --> 00:01:25.159
>> Yeah,
one of the things we hear a lot is, well,

29
00:01:25.159 --> 00:01:29.040
when I deploy a database into Azure,
I don't have to worry about it.

30
00:01:29.040 --> 00:01:30.462
Microsoft's backing it up.

31
00:01:30.462 --> 00:01:32.921
And if a server fails,
Microsoft's restoring it.

32
00:01:32.921 --> 00:01:34.538
They deal with everything, don't they?

33
00:01:34.538 --> 00:01:37.530
Well, not entirely.

34
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:40.296
So from a infrastructure standpoint,
yes, they take care of everything.

35
00:01:40.296 --> 00:01:43.441
I don't have to worry about that if
a hard drive fails at Microsoft side,

36
00:01:43.441 --> 00:01:44.420
they deal with that.

37
00:01:44.420 --> 00:01:45.671
It's covered.

38
00:01:45.671 --> 00:01:49.688
And if I'm doing a geo-replicated
server and an entire data center fails,

39
00:01:49.688 --> 00:01:52.336
Microsoft flips me over
to the other data center.

40
00:01:52.336 --> 00:01:52.962
They take care that.

41
00:01:52.962 --> 00:01:55.950
I don't have to worry about those things.

42
00:01:55.950 --> 00:01:59.560
But what they don't protect
you from is yourself.

43
00:01:59.560 --> 00:02:03.340
If I go into a database and I delete
a table, I just dropped the whole table,

44
00:02:03.340 --> 00:02:04.480
all that data is gone.

45
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:07.253
Well, Microsoft assumes that
I knew what I was doing.

46
00:02:07.253 --> 00:02:08.580
[LAUGH] Maybe naively, I don't know.

47
00:02:08.580 --> 00:02:11.670
They assume that the end user
knows what they're doing.

48
00:02:11.670 --> 00:02:14.340
And when we delete that table,
it's now gone.

49
00:02:14.340 --> 00:02:16.940
And if I wanna get it back, what can I do?

50
00:02:16.940 --> 00:02:19.300
Well, I've gotta go to my backups.

51
00:02:19.300 --> 00:02:22.690
And as far as the backups are concerned,
Microsoft sets that up for us, also.

52
00:02:22.690 --> 00:02:26.670
So when you fire up an Azure SQL database,
even if you don't even think about

53
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:31.280
backups, you just turn it on and let it
go, Microsoft is already backing that up.

54
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:36.740
And in a significant enough failure,
Microsoft will use that to restore,

55
00:02:36.740 --> 00:02:38.790
to get your database back online.

56
00:02:38.790 --> 00:02:42.620
But for minor things, for human errors,
for things that we delete or whatever,

57
00:02:42.620 --> 00:02:44.730
we've gotta jump in and
be able to get that back.

58
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:49.060
So I wanna take a look at that kind
of backup operation first, and

59
00:02:49.060 --> 00:02:50.730
then we'll take a look at
the restore side of it.

60
00:02:50.730 --> 00:02:54.190
So on the backup side, Microsoft
does something really interesting.

61
00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:55.380
Now, I've set up backups.

62
00:02:55.380 --> 00:02:56.878
Daniel, you've set up backups.

63
00:02:56.878 --> 00:03:00.814
When you backup an average server,
what's your normal backup interval,

64
00:03:00.814 --> 00:03:02.629
how often do you normally backup?

65
00:03:02.629 --> 00:03:06.879
>> We do a full backup weekly and
then incremental backups daily.

66
00:03:06.879 --> 00:03:08.340
>> And
that's a pretty common backup strategy.

67
00:03:08.340 --> 00:03:12.481
Because the full backup, it could take
hours, depending on the size of your data,

68
00:03:12.481 --> 00:03:15.853
and then you incremental backups
throughout the week because those

69
00:03:15.853 --> 00:03:19.840
are a lot faster, they're smaller sets,
it's just what's changed.

70
00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:21.886
And so you just back that up,
and it goes faster.

71
00:03:21.886 --> 00:03:27.031
But if you're backing up once a day,
let's say you're backing up at midnight,

72
00:03:27.031 --> 00:03:29.770
and you have a database failure at 11 PM.

73
00:03:31.370 --> 00:03:34.130
How much data did you just lose?

74
00:03:34.130 --> 00:03:35.590
You just lost 23 hours of data.

75
00:03:35.590 --> 00:03:37.330
That's pretty significant.

76
00:03:37.330 --> 00:03:40.520
We may want to backup
more rapidly than that

77
00:03:40.520 --> 00:03:45.510
to reduce our recovery time objective,
sorry, our recovery point objective.

78
00:03:45.510 --> 00:03:46.921
I gotta remember our backup terminology.

79
00:03:46.921 --> 00:03:49.030
So you have an RPO and an RTO.

80
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:53.255
The recovery point objective is how
much data you can afford to lose.

81
00:03:53.255 --> 00:03:56.913
And the recovery time objective is how
long you can afford to be down before you

82
00:03:56.913 --> 00:03:58.880
can get the system back online.

83
00:03:58.880 --> 00:04:03.092
And those values, RPO and RTO,
are really subjected to you,

84
00:04:03.092 --> 00:04:05.280
to your company and your needs.

85
00:04:05.280 --> 00:04:08.928
Daniel, you mentioned backing it up
once per day, that's pretty common for

86
00:04:08.928 --> 00:04:10.870
small businesses or noncritical data.

87
00:04:10.870 --> 00:04:15.667
But if it's mission-critical data, let's
say you're a hospital, or a financial

88
00:04:15.667 --> 00:04:20.214
institution, you're a bank, and
you're handling financial transactions.

89
00:04:20.214 --> 00:04:22.740
Can you lose 23 hours
worth of transactions?

90
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:23.700
Maybe?

91
00:04:23.700 --> 00:04:27.305
If you've been printing and saving the
paper receipt for every transaction and

92
00:04:27.305 --> 00:04:31.068
you lose 23 hours of data, you could have
people sit there with those receipts and

93
00:04:31.068 --> 00:04:32.879
redo the data entry after the failure.

94
00:04:32.879 --> 00:04:35.160
23 hours is not so bad.

95
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.180
Well, unless you're doing millions
of transactions per minute, and

96
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:40.470
then, it's not feasible anymore.

97
00:04:40.470 --> 00:04:43.730
So you might need to backup
more than one time a day.

98
00:04:43.730 --> 00:04:47.046
You might need to backup
more than one time an hour.

99
00:04:47.046 --> 00:04:49.461
Take, for example, Amazon.com.

100
00:04:49.461 --> 00:04:50.989
If they lost an hour of data,

101
00:04:50.989 --> 00:04:54.910
that's millions of dollars in
transactions that they performed.

102
00:04:54.910 --> 00:04:59.140
So they backup much more
frequently than that.

103
00:04:59.140 --> 00:05:03.979
I read a paper once, and they were doing
these constant transactional backups

104
00:05:03.979 --> 00:05:05.980
that were basically real time.

105
00:05:05.980 --> 00:05:09.879
And with Azure SQL,
Microsoft does that for you too.

106
00:05:09.879 --> 00:05:15.035
With Azure SQL, the default is that it's
backing up your data every 60 seconds.

107
00:05:15.035 --> 00:05:17.296
>> Whoa.
>> Once a minute.

108
00:05:17.296 --> 00:05:19.146
And I know that sounds pretty excessive,
but

109
00:05:19.146 --> 00:05:22.310
the way that it works is they backup your
database the moment you create it, so

110
00:05:22.310 --> 00:05:25.740
the moment you create it,
there's a full backup that's done.

111
00:05:25.740 --> 00:05:28.204
And then as changes
are entered into your database,

112
00:05:28.204 --> 00:05:31.004
every 60 seconds Microsoft
is capturing those changes.

113
00:05:31.004 --> 00:05:33.171
They're basically doing
transaction log backups.

114
00:05:33.171 --> 00:05:34.587
And they're doing that every 60 seconds.

115
00:05:34.587 --> 00:05:37.140
You don't even have to set it up.

116
00:05:37.140 --> 00:05:40.214
And this is on the cheapest database
to the most expensive database, so

117
00:05:40.214 --> 00:05:43.045
it's not like a higher tier's
gonna get me a better backup here.

118
00:05:43.045 --> 00:05:47.993
At the basic tier, I'm still getting
backups every 60 seconds, very,

119
00:05:47.993 --> 00:05:49.110
very granular.

120
00:05:49.110 --> 00:05:54.234
But what is different between the backup
tiers is how far that retention is,

121
00:05:54.234 --> 00:05:56.087
how far back I can restore.

122
00:05:56.087 --> 00:06:00.038
And basically to break it down like this,
on a basic data base,

123
00:06:00.038 --> 00:06:03.220
it's got a seven day retention period.

124
00:06:03.220 --> 00:06:06.161
If I do a standard, like an S0 through S5,

125
00:06:06.161 --> 00:06:09.670
the standards have a retention
period of 14 days.

126
00:06:09.670 --> 00:06:12.868
And then if you do one of the premium
databases, one of the high end,

127
00:06:12.868 --> 00:06:15.300
the expensive ones,
they're actually 35 day.

128
00:06:15.300 --> 00:06:18.449
So you're basically looking at one week,
two weeks, and

129
00:06:18.449 --> 00:06:22.129
then a full month that they'll
retain a backup every 60 seconds.

130
00:06:22.129 --> 00:06:23.880
So it's a pretty impressive number.

131
00:06:23.880 --> 00:06:26.340
And if you forget those numbers, don't
worry about it, here let me show you.

132
00:06:26.340 --> 00:06:30.860
When you go to create a database,
so if I go into Azure Portal, and

133
00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:34.530
I jump into SQL databases, and
I go to add a database in.

134
00:06:34.530 --> 00:06:36.479
When I go to create that database,

135
00:06:36.479 --> 00:06:39.379
it's going to ask me to
pick the performance tier.

136
00:06:39.379 --> 00:06:44.621
And when I go into the performance tier,
and you start looking at

137
00:06:44.621 --> 00:06:51.730
the difference between those performance
tiers, it's not showing it, is it?

138
00:06:51.730 --> 00:06:56.280
It used to show it right on here,
well shoot, now I'm misleading you guys.

139
00:06:56.280 --> 00:06:59.789
It used to show it right on here what
that data retention period was, and

140
00:06:59.789 --> 00:07:02.253
now I guess they've changed it,
so it doesn't.

141
00:07:02.253 --> 00:07:06.503
So you see Point In Time Restore,
there you go if you mouse over it.

142
00:07:06.503 --> 00:07:10.118
So here I am on a premium, and
if I float over Point In Time Restore,

143
00:07:10.118 --> 00:07:13.171
there see how it says
Point In Time Restore, 35 days.

144
00:07:13.171 --> 00:07:16.820
So it's gonna maintain backups
every 60 seconds for 35 days.

145
00:07:16.820 --> 00:07:20.242
And if I start to look at some of these
other ones like the standard, and

146
00:07:20.242 --> 00:07:23.960
I float over that same Point In Time
Restore, I'll get a little mouse over.

147
00:07:23.960 --> 00:07:27.320
And I guess my head's on top of that,
but it says 14 days,

148
00:07:27.320 --> 00:07:30.088
let me see if I can get it
different on the screen.

149
00:07:30.088 --> 00:07:31.660
And here we go.

150
00:07:31.660 --> 00:07:35.921
So here's that standard one, and if I
float over that, we can see the 14 days.

151
00:07:35.921 --> 00:07:40.550
And if we go down to the basic one here at
the bottom, Point in Time Restore, 7 days.

152
00:07:40.550 --> 00:07:42.879
So I'm getting at least
a solid week of backups.

153
00:07:42.879 --> 00:07:46.098
Now, remember, Microsoft is
protecting us from hardware failure.

154
00:07:46.098 --> 00:07:48.898
If a power supply dies,
if a hard drive dies,

155
00:07:48.898 --> 00:07:53.422
Microsoft's got us covered even if
you don't have geo-replication.

156
00:07:53.422 --> 00:07:56.522
So on some of the higher tiers,
I can do Standard Geo-Replication.

157
00:07:56.522 --> 00:07:58.275
Or active geo replication,

158
00:07:58.275 --> 00:08:02.720
where I've got a copy of my data
in another data center somewhere.

159
00:08:02.720 --> 00:08:06.070
So if one copy fails, the other one
just immediately goes active, but

160
00:08:06.070 --> 00:08:12.010
even on a basic where you don't have
replication, if the physical server fails,

161
00:08:12.010 --> 00:08:14.920
Microsoft will take the most
recent backup of your server,

162
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:16.940
restore it to new hardware and
bring it back online.

163
00:08:16.940 --> 00:08:18.120
That's automatic.

164
00:08:18.120 --> 00:08:20.720
Right, so on a hardware failure, right,

165
00:08:20.720 --> 00:08:24.660
infrastructure level, Microsoft will take
care of you, even on a network level.

166
00:08:24.660 --> 00:08:26.020
If the network connectivity for

167
00:08:26.020 --> 00:08:28.660
that data center dies, they'll
restore you at another data center,

168
00:08:28.660 --> 00:08:32.100
because the backups are being stored
in different replicated areas.

169
00:08:32.100 --> 00:08:34.750
So, they actually store
three copies of your backup.

170
00:08:34.750 --> 00:08:38.460
Two in the same availability zone
as what your main system is, and

171
00:08:38.460 --> 00:08:40.850
one more somewhere else, and so
that's how they're able to restore that.

172
00:08:40.850 --> 00:08:43.790
So, we get some really
good coverage there and

173
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:45.920
the ability to restore
that stuff pretty quickly.

174
00:08:47.090 --> 00:08:50.290
What it doesn't do,
is the user stuff, right.

175
00:08:50.290 --> 00:08:54.340
So if I delete a table,
well, if I delete a table or

176
00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:59.029
if somebody we accidentally drop a table,
we do a bad data import, we need to go and

177
00:08:59.029 --> 00:09:03.172
restore, right, and we're normally gonna
know that in less than seven days.

178
00:09:03.172 --> 00:09:05.400
[LAUGH] We know it in a few minutes,
right?

179
00:09:05.400 --> 00:09:09.180
I try to batch import 1,000 rows or
10,000 or 1 million rows, and

180
00:09:09.180 --> 00:09:12.820
something goes completely crazy,
I know right then I need to do a restore.

181
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:14.490
And I don't wanna do
a restore back seven days,

182
00:09:14.490 --> 00:09:16.450
I just wanna restore a few minutes, right.

183
00:09:16.450 --> 00:09:20.437
And so the seven days is really enough
even for the premium databases.

184
00:09:20.437 --> 00:09:23.940
But on the premium databases it's nice to
be able to go all the way back to 35 days.

185
00:09:23.940 --> 00:09:28.370
>> Now, Don, if we do have to dive
into doing a point in time restore,

186
00:09:28.370 --> 00:09:30.230
what kind of down time are we looking at?

187
00:09:30.230 --> 00:09:32.940
Is that gonna bring my network
down to a standstill and

188
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:36.440
I've gotta send out a blast email saying
hey, the database is unavailable for

189
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:39.480
the next two hours while we restore it?

190
00:09:39.480 --> 00:09:42.020
Not really, and
the reason is the way the restore works.

191
00:09:42.020 --> 00:09:45.451
Normally when we think of a restore,
what do you think?

192
00:09:45.451 --> 00:09:48.181
Do you think the current
database goes away and

193
00:09:48.181 --> 00:09:52.480

00:22:46.294 --> 00:22:48.100
Like that, all right.

452
00:22:48.100 --> 00:22:51.180
Now once I've got that in place,
I just need to run that stored procedure.

453
00:22:51.180 --> 00:22:54.620
So we'll just highlight that and
run it, and

454
00:22:54.620 --> 00:22:56.690
now that it's run we can pull up our list.

455
00:22:58.450 --> 00:23:03.360
And I can see that I now have
a database firewall rule right there.

456
00:23:03.360 --> 00:23:08.330
And Don_Home, this IP is now
allowed to access this database.

457
00:23:08.330 --> 00:23:10.200
Not allowed to access sample DB2,

458
00:23:10.200 --> 00:23:12.915
not allowed to access the master database,
right.

459
00:23:12.915 --> 00:23:16.632
I might want to add this to the master
database too if I need to connect to it,

460
00:23:16.632 --> 00:23:18.877
but I am allowed to
access this one database.

461
00:23:18.877 --> 00:23:22.737
Now if 209.251.159.180 is
covered by the server rule,

462
00:23:22.737 --> 00:23:27.050
then I'll be able to access everything,
regardless of what these say, right.

463
00:23:27.050 --> 00:23:30.540
So be aware of that, but otherwise I'm
now approved, and I can continue that and

464
00:23:30.540 --> 00:23:34.030
more by calling
sp_set_database_firewall_rule.

465
00:23:34.030 --> 00:23:36.880
You've also got
sp_delete_database_firewall_rule, and

466
00:23:36.880 --> 00:23:39.388
you would basically just eliminate
this stuff here at the end.

467
00:23:39.388 --> 00:23:43.310
And say sp_delete_database_firewall_rule
and then the name of the rule and

468
00:23:43.310 --> 00:23:44.670
it'll delete it out of there, right.

469
00:23:44.670 --> 00:23:48.810
So these are database level firewall
rules and they are a great way for

470
00:23:48.810 --> 00:23:50.910
giving you that granular control.

471
00:23:50.910 --> 00:23:54.530
There is another reason why these
are really handy though, okay.

472
00:23:54.530 --> 00:24:00.380
What happens if you back up your
database and something happens, right?

473
00:24:00.380 --> 00:24:03.060
And you need to do a restore and
your restore your database.

474
00:24:03.060 --> 00:24:06.240
Well, if you restore your
database to the same server

475
00:24:06.240 --> 00:24:08.880
then the server firewall
rules are already there.

476
00:24:08.880 --> 00:24:12.350
But if you restore your
database to another server,

477
00:24:12.350 --> 00:24:14.950
the server firewall rules aren't there,
right.

478
00:24:14.950 --> 00:24:18.310
So, they don't follow you,
they're not what's considered portable.

479
00:24:18.310 --> 00:24:22.330
The cool thing about database firewall
rules is they're stored in the database.

480
00:24:22.330 --> 00:24:24.300
So if I back up my database and

481
00:24:24.300 --> 00:24:27.860
I restore it to another server,
these rules follow it.

482
00:24:27.860 --> 00:24:31.770
And for that reason alone Microsoft
encourages you to use these if you can,

483
00:24:31.770 --> 00:24:34.370
cuz they'll follow your
database when there's restores,

484
00:24:34.370 --> 00:24:36.690
when you move server names, all right.

485
00:24:36.690 --> 00:24:38.320
These rules will follow it along, and

486
00:24:38.320 --> 00:24:40.330
these people will always
have access to the database.

487
00:24:40.330 --> 00:24:41.680
You may not want that, right.

488
00:24:41.680 --> 00:24:44.290
If you are creating a dev or
staging environment you may not want

489
00:24:44.290 --> 00:24:46.320
the same permissions that
you had on the database and

490
00:24:46.320 --> 00:24:49.970
production, and in that scenario
a server firewalls rule may be better.

491
00:24:49.970 --> 00:24:52.090
It's up to you to kind of choose, right.

492
00:24:52.090 --> 00:24:54.620
But just remember that they are not
compatible with each other.

493
00:24:54.620 --> 00:24:58.370
The server rules always beat
out the database rules.

494
00:24:58.370 --> 00:25:00.220
And so you just need to be
aware of that as you kinda

495
00:25:00.220 --> 00:25:01.810
implement this in your environment.

496
00:25:01.810 --> 00:25:05.040
But once you get them created,
they're in place and now you've got little

497
00:25:05.040 --> 00:25:09.340
mini firewalls on each database so
you can have that granular access.

498
00:25:09.340 --> 00:25:13.120
Somebody can access on database but not
another one and you've got that control.

499
00:25:13.120 --> 00:25:16.532
>> So Don yeah, we have a lot of
really good security tips here for

500
00:25:16.532 --> 00:25:19.030
your SQL environment cuz obviously,
like we said before,

501
00:25:19.030 --> 00:25:23.760
this is where the actual gold is
that hackers might want to go after.

502
00:25:23.760 --> 00:25:26.630
So you got a lot of good ways
in which we can secure it up.

503
00:25:26.630 --> 00:25:29.780
Is there anything else that we need
to cover when it comes to security or

504
00:25:29.780 --> 00:25:31.200
maybe a firewall rule or something?

505
00:25:31.200 --> 00:25:34.870
>> Yeah, one big enemy to firewall rules

506
00:25:34.870 --> 00:25:37.090
is that your client's IP
addresses can change, right.

507
00:25:37.090 --> 00:25:41.230
If your client's using DHCP or if they're
going through a NAT router, they might

508
00:25:41.230 --> 00:25:45.320
have one public IP address today and
a different public IP address next week.

509
00:25:45.320 --> 00:25:47.520
That happens pretty frequently and
as you travel and

510
00:25:47.520 --> 00:25:49.650
move from office to
office your IP changes.

511
00:25:49.650 --> 00:25:53.785
So you'll find that maintaining your
firewall rules can be pretty significant.

512
00:25:53.785 --> 00:25:54.890
And so

513
00:25:54.890 --> 00:25:59.780
from that perspective sometimes it's
easier if you set up a VPN into Azure.

514
00:25:59.780 --> 00:26:00.930
And that way you VPN in and

515
00:26:00.930 --> 00:26:03.770
you get assigned an IP and you've
always got an IP in a certain range.

516
00:26:03.770 --> 00:26:06.860
That can actually be a little helpful
to save that time for an administrator.

517
00:26:06.860 --> 00:26:08.920
But in terms of servers,
you can't really do that.

518
00:26:08.920 --> 00:26:12.400
So that's where you got to make sure
you've got static IPs if you can, or,

519
00:26:12.400 --> 00:26:15.660
just be ready to do some firewall rule
maintenance on a pretty regular basis,

520
00:26:15.660 --> 00:26:17.300
just as people's IPs change.

521
00:26:17.300 --> 00:26:18.150
Just be aware of that.

522
00:26:18.150 --> 00:26:19.630
>> Just part of the job.

523
00:26:19.630 --> 00:26:20.170
>> Job security.

524
00:26:20.170 --> 00:26:21.150
>> That's right, job security.

525
00:26:21.150 --> 00:26:21.980
Always good stuff.

526
00:26:21.980 --> 00:26:23.620
Well thank you so much for
explaining this for

527
00:26:23.620 --> 00:26:26.860
us today, and
we thank you out there for watching.

528
00:26:26.860 --> 00:26:29.550
But this concludes yet
another great episode here at ITProTV.

529
00:26:29.550 --> 00:26:31.120
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

530
00:26:31.120 --> 00:26:32.470
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

531
00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:33.090
>> And I'm Don Pizzette.

532
00:26:33.090 --> 00:26:34.002
>> And we'll see you next time.

533
00:26:34.002 --> 00:26:40.180
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain the different user account and roles implemented in Azure SQL. They being by opening the Azure Web Portal and setting up a server management administrator and describing all the possible roles available which grants permissions. Then they look at creating regular database users by using T-SQL with the SQL Management Studio and configure the default database roles, again for access permissions.
episodes.title: Users and Roles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.352 --> 00:00:12.970
All right.

3
00:00:12.970 --> 00:00:13.680
Greetings everyone.

4
00:00:13.680 --> 00:00:16.469
And welcome to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.469 --> 00:00:19.184
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:19.184 --> 00:00:22.376
we're continuing on that Azure SQL Series
we've been working so hard on.

7
00:00:22.376 --> 00:00:27.297
And joining me again today in the studio,
that's right I've pried him away from his

8
00:00:27.297 --> 00:00:31.910
Steam account to help us out with that
Azure SQL, that is good man, Don Pezet.

9
00:00:31.910 --> 00:00:33.050
Don, welcome back to the show, sir.

10
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:33.630
How you doing?

11
00:00:33.630 --> 00:00:34.480
>> Doing great, Daniel.

12
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:35.690
Thanks for having me back,

13
00:00:35.690 --> 00:00:38.670
ready to jump right back in to
that world of Microsoft Azure SQL.

14
00:00:38.670 --> 00:00:42.110
We're gonna continue on with our security
episodes today and take a look at how we

15
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:47.000
manage user accounts inside of Azure SQL
and it's kinda an important thing.

16
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:49.250
You're not just gonna have one
person who logs into the database,

17
00:00:49.250 --> 00:00:50.660
you'll likely have more and so

18
00:00:50.660 --> 00:00:55.200
we need to be able to control that access
and gate who can get into the system.

19
00:00:55.200 --> 00:00:58.770
>> So Don, when I think of user accounts
obviously our mind goes straight to

20
00:00:58.770 --> 00:01:02.700
the almighty dictator of the system,
that is the administrator.

21
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:05.300
They are obviously type
of a user account so

22
00:01:05.300 --> 00:01:07.090
I guess that's a good place for
us to begin.

23
00:01:07.090 --> 00:01:10.140
>> Yeah, absolutely, and
there's really two different sets of

24
00:01:10.140 --> 00:01:14.900
credentials that happen inside of Azure
SQL, because when you create a database,

25
00:01:14.900 --> 00:01:18.890
one of the first things it asks you is
to give it a username and a password.

26
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:23.090
And as a username and password in
the database itself, but In the background

27
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:28.170
what we don't see is that it's actually
taking your user account in Azure and

28
00:01:28.170 --> 00:01:31.330
adding you as somebody who's
allowed to manage that server.

29
00:01:31.330 --> 00:01:35.620
Now that's important because you may have
many administrators on your account.

30
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:37.210
You take my account, for example.

31
00:01:37.210 --> 00:01:38.090
I'm an administrator, sure.

32
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:41.340
But so is Daniel and so
are the other show hosts here at ITProTV,

33
00:01:41.340 --> 00:01:44.070
that each one Is allowed
to manage the account but

34
00:01:44.070 --> 00:01:48.950
when I create a SQL Server,
I'm the administrator not Daniel.

35
00:01:48.950 --> 00:01:49.920
He can't get at it.

36
00:01:49.920 --> 00:01:52.340
Right or Mike or Ronnie or any of
the other hosts, they can't get at it.

37
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:55.530
I have to add them in if
I want them to have it.

38
00:01:55.530 --> 00:01:59.090
So that needs to be one of the first steps
we do, anytime we spin up a new server is

39
00:01:59.090 --> 00:02:03.860
to determine who should have access to the
server from an administrative standpoint?

40
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:06.300
That dictator, right, the person
who's in charge of the whole thing.

41
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:07.640
So let me show you how that works.

42
00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:09.810
Basically, I'm gonna go
into my Azure portal, and

43
00:02:09.810 --> 00:02:12.220
I'm gonna go down to SQL Servers.

44
00:02:12.220 --> 00:02:14.650
And inside of my SQL Servers,
I'll pick a server.

45
00:02:16.050 --> 00:02:17.410
And from here,

46
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:21.880
over on the side here I'm gonna start
getting all my different settings pop up.

47
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:27.230
And way down here at the bottom,
I've Resource Management and Users.

48
00:02:27.230 --> 00:02:31.130
There's really two things that
matter to me here, Users and Roles.

49
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:36.280
Users are the people who are allowed
to connect and manage this server.

50
00:02:36.280 --> 00:02:39.160
I shouldn't say connect cuz you don't
necessarily have to have a user

51
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:41.840
here to connect to
the databases themselves.

52
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:45.110
So this is really to manage it, so these
are users who are allowed to manage it.

53
00:02:45.110 --> 00:02:48.600
And then roles are basically
the permissions they have.

54
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:50.850
When I say manage it, what can they do?

55
00:02:50.850 --> 00:02:53.740
There's different levels of
management that you might need.

56
00:02:53.740 --> 00:02:54.800
And so we can specify them here.

57
00:02:54.800 --> 00:02:56.100
These two work hand in hand.

58
00:02:57.280 --> 00:03:00.872
The first thing I need to do is create
Users, and if I click on Users,

59
00:03:00.872 --> 00:03:02.461
that panel's gonna update.

60
00:03:02.461 --> 00:03:06.797
And I'm gonna get a list of
the users on that database, and

61
00:03:06.797 --> 00:03:10.263
the only thing I see
are Subscription admins.

62
00:03:10.263 --> 00:03:12.980
Now who are the Subscription admins?

63
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:14.110
Me.

64
00:03:14.110 --> 00:03:15.450
I'm the one who runs this account.

65
00:03:15.450 --> 00:03:17.290
I'm the one who's the administrator for
my subscription,

66
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:18.860
in other words the person
who pays the money.

67
00:03:18.860 --> 00:03:20.170
And so I'm on here.

68
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:21.280
I created this server.

69
00:03:21.280 --> 00:03:21.810
I get access.

70
00:03:21.810 --> 00:03:22.770
I control it.

71
00:03:22.770 --> 00:03:26.700
I am the owner and that's Inherited
access from my Azure account.

72
00:03:26.700 --> 00:03:29.100
But now I can come in and
I can add other people.

73
00:03:29.100 --> 00:03:29.990
So, for example, Daniel,

74
00:03:29.990 --> 00:03:34.130
he's an administrator on my Azure account,
but he's not the one paying the bill and

75
00:03:34.130 --> 00:03:37.960
so he's not a Subscription admin,
he doesn't have access to the server.

76
00:03:37.960 --> 00:03:40.770
If I want him to have access,
I need to come up here and hit Add, and

77
00:03:40.770 --> 00:03:43.300
I can make him an administrator.

78
00:03:43.300 --> 00:03:46.130
And so when I add that, oop,
I get a little scroll crazy.

79
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:48.740
The first thing it's gonna do
is ask me to pick a role, and

80
00:03:48.740 --> 00:03:51.830
then it's gonna ask me to pick a user,
okay.

81
00:03:51.830 --> 00:03:56.290
So here's that role coming in hand in hand
with the user, roles are useless without

82
00:03:56.290 --> 00:03:59.920
users in them, and users are useless
without a role assigned to them.

83
00:03:59.920 --> 00:04:02.880
And so I would need to pick what kind of
role I want Daniel to have and maybe,

84
00:04:02.880 --> 00:04:04.260
I want him to be an owner.

85
00:04:04.260 --> 00:04:08.355
I want him to have full control of this
sequence since he's gonna help me and

86
00:04:08.355 --> 00:04:09.590
do this work.

87
00:04:09.590 --> 00:04:12.940
>> Now Don, how are roles any
different from something like a group?

88
00:04:12.940 --> 00:04:14.500
>> They really are groups.

89
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.091
Microsoft just started moving away
from that terminology of a group.

90
00:04:17.091 --> 00:04:18.834
Because the group, kind of,

91
00:04:18.834 --> 00:04:22.899
it insinuates that the people are all
part of the same organization.

92
00:04:22.899 --> 00:04:27.345
And they aren't necessarily, and
a role is more like what your job role is.

93
00:04:27.345 --> 00:04:30.388
So, it's a little more of nebulous term,
and so

94
00:04:30.388 --> 00:04:33.222
Microsoft has kind of
transitioned to that.

95
00:04:33.222 --> 00:04:35.910
So, it's really basically the same thing.

96
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:39.560
So, when I go here under User,
notice what I'm seeing,

97
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:43.260
a list of users attached to my account and
I'll see Daniel right there.

98
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:47.390
Now, this have to be users already
added to my Azure account.

99
00:04:47.390 --> 00:04:50.552
This isn't part of Azure SQL,
this is part of Azure itself.

100
00:04:50.552 --> 00:04:54.234
And so Daniel is an administrator here in
my account so I can choose him and Adam.

101
00:04:54.234 --> 00:04:57.840
And I can choose other people, like if
I want to list myself specifically.

102
00:04:57.840 --> 00:05:02.050
Maybe one day I'm gonna take myself
out of the subscription management,

103
00:05:02.050 --> 00:05:03.460
I'll make somebody else pay for it.

104
00:05:03.460 --> 00:05:06.050
Then I might want to add myself
specifically so I still have access.

105
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:11.180
So we pick the users that we're gonna be
adding and then I'll just hit Select.

106
00:05:11.180 --> 00:05:16.510
And so now I've told it the role I want
the users to have and I picked some users.

107
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:18.470
And I'll go down here and I'll hit OK.

108
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:23.420
And once that's done,
this will update eventually.

109
00:05:23.420 --> 00:05:24.220
There we go.

110
00:05:24.220 --> 00:05:27.090
And now I can see those two
users listed as an owner.

111
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:30.740
These users now have access
to manage this SQL Server.

112
00:05:30.740 --> 00:05:34.190
And inherently through that,
because they can manage the SQL Server,

113
00:05:34.190 --> 00:05:36.180
they can manage the databases
that are underneath it.

114
00:05:36.180 --> 00:05:37.950
Which is kind of an important thing.

115
00:05:37.950 --> 00:05:40.630
Now, the users are one piece of that.

116
00:05:40.630 --> 00:05:42.950
The roles of the other and I chose owner.

117
00:05:42.950 --> 00:05:47.565
Owner, that gives full and
total control to every aspect of system.

118
00:05:47.565 --> 00:05:50.445
But there's plenty of other roles
that we need to familiar with.

119
00:05:50.445 --> 00:05:52.920
Now we're gonna take a look
at those other roles.

120
00:05:52.920 --> 00:05:55.730
We have a nice little shortcut here
we can jump to to get to the roles.

121
00:05:55.730 --> 00:05:57.900
Or you can do it from the server itself.

122
00:05:57.900 --> 00:05:59.089
If I go back to the server,

123
00:06:00.380 --> 00:06:04.590
we actually had that option right over,
why can't I zoom in on that?

124
00:06:04.590 --> 00:06:05.610
My zooms going crazy here.

125
00:06:05.610 --> 00:06:08.172
But we have that option right over here,
we can get to roles, and

126
00:06:08.172 --> 00:06:10.319
we can take a look at the roles
that are on that server.

127
00:06:10.319 --> 00:06:15.368
So, here's the roles that Microsoft
creates, and you can create custom roles.

128
00:06:15.368 --> 00:06:19.542
But really the ones that are here, it's
pretty much what everybody needs cuz most

129
00:06:19.542 --> 00:06:22.162
of the time you're just
gonna use Owner like I did.

130
00:06:22.162 --> 00:06:24.275
See Owner., it's got two users.

131
00:06:24.275 --> 00:06:27.073
These are people that have full and
total control of the server.

132
00:06:27.073 --> 00:06:29.975
But sometimes,
I wanna limit them a little bit.

133
00:06:29.975 --> 00:06:33.447
And that's where all of these
other ones start to come in.

134
00:06:33.447 --> 00:06:38.800
We've got Contributor, Reader, Database
Contributor, Security Manager and so on.

135
00:06:38.800 --> 00:06:42.650
If we kinda run down the list,
you get this eye you can float over and

136
00:06:42.650 --> 00:06:43.740
it will tell you a little about it.

137
00:06:43.740 --> 00:06:48.330
See how this one says you can manage
everything except access to resources.

138
00:06:48.330 --> 00:06:52.150
So in other words if I had given Daniel
Contributor, he can create databases and

139
00:06:52.150 --> 00:06:53.580
delete databases.

140
00:06:53.580 --> 00:06:55.940
But he couldn't give somebody else access.

141
00:06:55.940 --> 00:06:58.410
He couldn't make somebody else an owner,
for example, or

142
00:06:58.410 --> 00:07:00.110
give them to be able to
elevate his own privileges.

143
00:07:01.240 --> 00:07:04.560
Reader, this one's really useful for

00:11:21.800 --> 00:11:24.740

00:11:29.030 --> 00:11:32.130

00:12:02.770 --> 00:12:04.210

00:12:04.210 --> 00:12:07.360

00:12:07.360 --> 00:12:10.870

244
00:12:10.870 --> 00:12:14.060

much anymore, so
it's not that of a big of a deal.

00:18:16.505 --> 00:18:18.361

this process works.

00:18:18.361 --> 00:18:21.069

like I did before,

00:18:21.069 --> 00:18:23.841
I'm gonna go straight to
the database that I'm targerting.

371
00:18:23.841 --> 00:18:25.906
So, I'm connected to the sample DB2,

00:18:25.906 --> 00:18:29.500
and you can see the command where
I created for Daniel's account.

373
00:18:29.500 --> 00:18:32.110
I'm gonna create one for Ronnie,
one of other show hosts here.

00:18:32.110 --> 00:18:34.730
So, I wanna create a user for him.

00:18:34.730 --> 00:18:39.750
So, I'll say create user rwrong from and,

00:18:39.750 --> 00:18:43.970
instead of saying from login,

00:18:43.970 --> 00:18:47.210
From login, that's how I connect
to a login on the server.

00:18:47.210 --> 00:18:50.610
Instead, I'm just gonna say with password.

379
00:18:50.610 --> 00:18:52.462
And then I'm going to set what
I want his password to be.

00:18:52.462 --> 00:18:58.226
And by doing a with password, that's
what's telling it that I want to create

00:18:58.226 --> 00:19:04.880
one that's contained right here in this
database, and so that I can use it, right?

382
00:19:04.880 --> 00:19:09.340
So if I just execute that,
that's gonna create his user account,

383
00:19:09.340 --> 00:19:11.000
I get command completed successfully.

384
00:19:11.000 --> 00:19:15.410
It is not tied to a login but
it's functional,

385
00:19:15.410 --> 00:19:18.690
it's got a password, it just happens

386
00:19:18.690 --> 00:19:20.586
And if I refresh my users over here,

387
00:19:20.586 --> 00:19:25.090
I can see that I've got Daniel Lowrie

388
00:19:25.090 --> 00:19:27.140
Now, once they're created,

00:19:27.140 --> 00:19:30.310

00:19:30.310 --> 00:19:33.120

00:19:33.120 --> 00:19:36.860

00:19:36.860 --> 00:19:42.040
The other difference is,

00:19:42.040 --> 00:19:45.580
like with Daniel's, if he has

00:19:45.580 --> 00:19:48.510

00:19:48.510 --> 00:19:51.690
And if he changes his password, it's

396
00:19:51.690 --> 00:19:55.890
Versus Ronnie, his user account's

00:19:55.890 --> 00:19:56.900
If I add another database,

00:19:56.900 --> 00:19:59.150
I have to create another Ronnie
account in that database.

00:19:59.150 --> 00:20:02.520
It could have a different password,
or you change the password on one,

400
00:20:02.520 --> 00:20:03.680
it doesn't change on the other.

401
00:20:03.680 --> 00:20:05.990
So you get a little bit
more administrative burden.

402
00:20:05.990 --> 00:20:08.170
But you get portability,
and it's usually worth it.

403
00:20:08.170 --> 00:20:10.980
So Microsoft encourages you to do,
contained user accounts.

404
00:20:10.980 --> 00:20:13.900
It's kinda like the database
firewall rules we talked about

405
00:20:13.900 --> 00:20:15.150
in the other episode.

406
00:20:15.150 --> 00:20:17.100
You can do server level firewall rules,
but

407
00:20:17.100 --> 00:20:19.960
if you want portability,
you do database firewall rules.

408
00:20:19.960 --> 00:20:20.960
And same thing here,

409
00:20:20.960 --> 00:20:23.700
if you want portability you
do contained user accounts.

410
00:20:23.700 --> 00:20:27.070
And so a lot of times you'll need
to do that with your database.

411
00:20:27.070 --> 00:20:31.080
>> Well done, now that we have a couple of
actual users in this database, now it's

412
00:20:31.080 --> 00:20:34.970
time to start setting permissions and that
is done via the roles, is that correct?

413
00:20:34.970 --> 00:20:39.080
>> Correct, yeah, so when we look
at our SQL Management Studio here,

414
00:20:39.080 --> 00:20:41.610
just a little folder down are the Roles,
and

415
00:20:41.610 --> 00:20:44.240
I can start to look at
the database roles that are here.

416
00:20:44.240 --> 00:20:48.090
Now there are server level roles and you
generally don't want to use those, right?

417
00:20:48.090 --> 00:20:51.740
And again it goes back to portability,
but also users don't get the level

418
00:20:51.740 --> 00:20:54.640
administration on the server roles,
that's really for on premises stuff.

419
00:20:54.640 --> 00:20:59.500
So with Azure you've got the roles of
the server level we saw on the GUI

420
00:20:59.500 --> 00:21:00.940
in the web based portal, right?

421
00:21:00.940 --> 00:21:02.120
That's what you want to use.

422
00:21:02.120 --> 00:21:04.790
And then we've got
database roles right here.

423
00:21:04.790 --> 00:21:06.220
And these are the database roles,

424
00:21:06.220 --> 00:21:09.520
you can create custom roles that grant
all sorts of permissions if you want.

425
00:21:09.520 --> 00:21:11.500
These are just the default ones.

426
00:21:11.500 --> 00:21:15.270
And looking at these roles you'll
see db_accessadmin and so on.

427
00:21:15.270 --> 00:21:17.425
Each one has a different purpose,

428
00:21:17.425 --> 00:21:20.660
and these were all created back
in the on premises days, so

429
00:21:20.660 --> 00:21:23.532
some of them aren't really relevant
anymore, like db_backupoperator.

430
00:21:23.532 --> 00:21:26.490
db_backupoperator is allowed
to back up the database, and

431
00:21:26.490 --> 00:21:28.630
they're also allowed to restore it.

432
00:21:28.630 --> 00:21:32.660
Well the problem is, in Azure, you can't
do the traditional backup because you have

00:21:32.660 --> 00:21:35.200
to specify file name and
Azure doesn't support that, right?

434
00:21:35.200 --> 00:21:37.160
You use the backup

435
00:21:37.160 --> 00:21:41.008
So this role really doesn't serve much
purpose any more unless you just want to

436
00:21:41.008 --> 00:21:43.632
give somebody read access
to the whole database, but

437
00:21:43.632 --> 00:21:45.347
you can do that with other things.

438
00:21:45.347 --> 00:21:49.740
db_datareader, db_datawriter,
those are pretty important, right?

439
00:21:49.740 --> 00:21:52.430
These will let you read data from
the database and write data.

440
00:21:52.430 --> 00:21:54.110
So if you want somebody to
be able to make changes, or

441
00:21:54.110 --> 00:21:57.330
just have a read only view,
you can use those too, all right?

442
00:21:57.330 --> 00:21:59.460
Some of the other ones,
you've got access admin.

443
00:21:59.460 --> 00:22:01.950
This is a person who can create user
accounts in the database, right?

444
00:22:01.950 --> 00:22:04.770
And reset passwords and
manage permissions.

445
00:22:04.770 --> 00:22:07.660
You've got DDL,
the data definition language admin.

446
00:22:07.660 --> 00:22:09.970
This is the person who
creates stored procedures,

447
00:22:09.970 --> 00:22:13.540
right, miniature programs
that run from the server.

448
00:22:13.540 --> 00:22:16.680
You've got denydatareader and
denydatawriter.

449
00:22:16.680 --> 00:22:19.410
You absolutely don't want
somebody to be able to read, or

450
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:22.570
you absolutely don't want them to be able
to write, cuz somebody could be in more

451
00:22:22.570 --> 00:22:26.400
than one role, and so they might be
getting write permission accidentally.

452
00:22:26.400 --> 00:22:27.920
So, you can throw them in deny, and

453
00:22:27.920 --> 00:22:29.914
now they won't get it,
no matter what their other roles are.

454
00:22:29.914 --> 00:22:32.900
db_owner, that's what
we'll be in by default.

455
00:22:32.900 --> 00:22:33.780
So as the administrator,

456
00:22:33.780 --> 00:22:36.568
you and db_owner that gives you
that full control of the database.

457
00:22:36.568 --> 00:22:40.190
And then db_securityadmin,
that gives you permissions controls.

458
00:22:40.190 --> 00:22:42.530
So you can go in and change those as
well as those security credentials.

459
00:22:42.530 --> 00:22:44.470
And then you got public,

460
00:22:44.470 --> 00:22:48.150
these are the permissions that
apply to everybody else, right?

461
00:22:48.150 --> 00:22:50.130
If somebody comes in and
accesses the database and

462
00:22:50.130 --> 00:22:53.840
I have permissions I want to apply just
to anybody, I apply them to public.

463
00:22:53.840 --> 00:22:55.790
And then you can create
your own custom rules.

464
00:22:55.790 --> 00:22:58.520
Now, again, in the on premises world,

465
00:22:58.520 --> 00:23:02.410
we would just double click on one of
these and start to add users into it, but

466
00:23:02.410 --> 00:23:05.530
here in Azure SQL,
it's doesn't really work, right?

467
00:23:05.530 --> 00:23:07.360
So if I really want to add somebody in,

468
00:23:07.360 --> 00:23:11.140
maybe I want to make Daniel a db_owner,

469
00:23:11.140 --> 00:23:15.191
Or Ronnie or both of them, right, well we
just have to do a quick little query and

00:23:15.191 --> 00:23:16.773
we can knock that out, right?

471
00:23:16.773 --> 00:23:22.530
So over here if I want them to be admins,
I just need to add them into that role.

472
00:23:22.530 --> 00:23:27.115
And so we can call a little stored
procedure that does that, I'm gonna call

473
00:23:27.115 --> 00:23:33.789
?EXEC sp_addrolemember, and I'll specify
the role which I'm going to do db_owner.

474
00:23:35.410 --> 00:23:38.380
And then I specify who it
is I am gonna put in there.

475
00:23:38.380 --> 00:23:44.540
And so I will do dlowrie, and
then we will add Ronny next.

476
00:23:44.540 --> 00:23:48.910
So I will add that in so now he is in that
role, and then I can just go back in there

477
00:23:48.910 --> 00:23:54.090
and add rwong, and run that.

478
00:23:54.090 --> 00:23:55.760
And now they're both in that role, right?

479
00:23:55.760 --> 00:23:58.870
So now those two have permissions
they can actually do something.

480
00:23:58.870 --> 00:24:01.280
So with a contained user,
we've gotta create the user,

481
00:24:01.280 --> 00:24:05.210
and then we gotta put them in a role, and
then we can actually do something, right?

482
00:24:05.210 --> 00:24:08.440
With a traditional user, you've got
to create a log in, then you've got

483
00:24:08.440 --> 00:24:12.430
to map a user to the log in, and then
you've got to put a user in a role, so

484
00:24:12.430 --> 00:24:14.640
it's kind of three steps,
versus two steps.

485
00:24:14.640 --> 00:24:17.450
This way's a little easier,

you just lose a little bit of portability.

00:24:28.640 --> 00:24:33.220

caveats or tips that you've got for

494
00:24:42.950 --> 00:24:46.290
>> Mostly just to be aware that,

00:24:46.290 --> 00:24:49.180
if you've been a DBA or just

a lot of the GUI tools don't work when

00:24:54.700 --> 00:24:57.680

And then, you maybe tempted to go and

00:25:05.250 --> 00:25:06.630
it's a waste of time, right?

502
00:25:06.630 --> 00:25:08.360
Because those aren't gonna
follow your database,

503
00:25:08.360 --> 00:25:11.700
they're stuck to a server and for the most
part you're not allowed to edit them, so

00:25:11.700 --> 00:25:14.850
it's gonna scream at bit when

00:25:14.850 --> 00:25:17.070
So really you need to
use the web portal for

00:25:17.070 --> 00:25:19.220
the server level permissions, and then for

507
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:22.930
administrators, and then everybody else

508
00:25:22.930 --> 00:25:25.870
Create those contained users,

00:25:25.870 --> 00:25:28.530
we'll see a little more on

00:25:28.530 --> 00:25:31.950

00:25:31.950 --> 00:25:32.870
>> Excellent stuff, Don.

512
00:25:32.870 --> 00:25:35.846

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel dive into database permissions and schemas. They start by discussing database permissions and how they can be set on database objects like tables which will allow you to have very fine control over who can access that table. This leads them into describing setting permissions on users vs. groups/roles and when you would do one over the other. Finally they explain the idea of schemas which enables you to basically create a template to set permissions with an overarching scope.
episodes.title: Permissions and Schemas

For dbo.Employees, I'm gonna assign
permissions right on the employees table.

288
00:14:58.278 --> 00:15:03.200
But for hr.Payroll,
we can assign permissions to the schema.

289
00:15:03.200 --> 00:15:10.000
And if I have a user and I give them db
data reader permissions on the hr schema,

290
00:15:10.000 --> 00:15:13.550
they just got reader permissions on
everything that's in that schema.

291
00:15:13.550 --> 00:15:14.490
And that's pretty cool.

292
00:15:14.490 --> 00:15:16.280
That's a pretty convenient thing.

293
00:15:16.280 --> 00:15:19.100
And now as I create new
tables that are hr related,

294
00:15:19.100 --> 00:15:22.040
I just put them in that schema and
they'll inherit those permissions.

295
00:15:22.040 --> 00:15:26.090
It's just a great way to make sure that
we don't screw up and leak data out.

296
00:15:26.090 --> 00:15:29.250
Anytime you manage permissions
on individual objects,

297
00:15:29.250 --> 00:15:31.300
every time you add a new object,
you gotta redo those permissions.

298
00:15:31.300 --> 00:15:32.900
And that means there's a chance for
you to make a mistake.

299
00:15:32.900 --> 00:15:35.840
But when you assign
the permissions to a schema,

300
00:15:35.840 --> 00:15:39.370
Now we've got this one central set of
permissions, and they're basically getting

301
00:15:39.370 --> 00:15:41.940
reused every time we add a new object,
and it's nice and consistent.

302
00:15:41.940 --> 00:15:43.204
If I change it in the schema,

303
00:15:43.204 --> 00:15:46.930
it changes for all of the objects that
are a part of that and underneath that.

304
00:15:46.930 --> 00:15:49.730
So definitely a great technology and
definitely one you wanna make use of.

305
00:15:51.100 --> 00:15:55.325
However, you'll find a lot of people
out there don't use schemas, and

306
00:15:55.325 --> 00:15:56.650
you might wonder why.

307
00:15:56.650 --> 00:16:01.550
Well, if I wanna quarry data
from the employees table, or

308
00:16:01.550 --> 00:16:06.950
even the HR payroll table, right so,
if I were to do a new query.

309
00:16:06.950 --> 00:16:14.720
And I do, SELECT * FROM Employees.

310
00:16:14.720 --> 00:16:15.673
If I spell it, right this will work.

311
00:16:15.673 --> 00:16:17.113
>> [LAUGH]
>> There we go.

312
00:16:17.113 --> 00:16:19.360
If I do SELECT * FROM Employees, right?

313
00:16:19.360 --> 00:16:21.280
Give me all the data
from the Employees table.

314
00:16:21.280 --> 00:16:23.220
When I run that, it works, right?

315
00:16:24.410 --> 00:16:32.780
If I run SELECT * FROM Payroll,
and I run that, it doesn't work.

316
00:16:32.780 --> 00:16:35.020
Invalid object name.

317
00:16:35.020 --> 00:16:36.340
Well, there's a payroll table.

318
00:16:36.340 --> 00:16:37.122
I know there is, right?

319
00:16:37.122 --> 00:16:40.850
But it's failing.
So, why's it failing?

320
00:16:40.850 --> 00:16:44.850
Well, it's failing because
I didn't specify a schema.

321
00:16:44.850 --> 00:16:48.110
If you don't specify a schema,
it defaults to DBO.

322
00:16:48.110 --> 00:16:51.040
So if you leave all your
stuff in the DBO schema

323
00:16:51.040 --> 00:16:52.490
then you don't have to provide a schema.

324
00:16:52.490 --> 00:16:55.500
There's a lot of database admins
out there that like that.

325
00:16:55.500 --> 00:16:59.500
But, you lose the advantage of having
this kind of like shared permission.

326
00:16:59.500 --> 00:17:03.750
If you use schemas, every time you
query an object in that schema you have

327
00:17:03.750 --> 00:17:05.130
to type the schema before it.

328
00:17:05.130 --> 00:17:10.110
So if I wanna query payroll,
I've actually got a query hr.payroll.

329
00:17:10.110 --> 00:17:13.710
And so, when I do that I can execute
it and there it is, my table is empty,

330
00:17:13.710 --> 00:17:14.810
it's not very exiting.

331
00:17:14.810 --> 00:17:18.430
But it's just one extra little bit to do
and so a lot of people don't like that.

332
00:17:18.430 --> 00:17:21.620
And if you've got an old database,
one that was written back in the old owner

333
00:17:21.620 --> 00:17:26.020
days, most people just left it to DBO and
all of your stuff might be DBO right now.

334
00:17:26.020 --> 00:17:29.501
And so people might be resistant to going
to schemas, but if you're implementing

335
00:17:29.501 --> 00:17:32.996
something new, absolutely 100% use
the schemas as what they're there for.

336
00:17:32.996 --> 00:17:36.807
Gives you extra security control and
it prevents mistakes, it's definitely

337
00:17:36.807 --> 00:17:40.573
something you wanna implement and
get put in place, it really is important.

338
00:17:40.573 --> 00:17:41.166
All right.

339
00:17:41.166 --> 00:17:44.964
And you know technically is there a lot
more that goes on you have an owner and

340
00:17:44.964 --> 00:17:48.946
server name sort of fully qualified name
for any object in the database section

341
00:17:48.946 --> 00:17:53.180
contains four parts but,
it assumes defaults for certain things.

342
00:17:53.180 --> 00:17:57.490
And you know, while I'm mentioning
defaults, when you create a user account,

343
00:17:57.490 --> 00:18:01.500
you can actually specify what
their default schema is.

344
00:18:01.500 --> 00:18:04.850
So, for example,
my default schema right now is DBO.

345
00:18:04.850 --> 00:18:09.400
And that's why when I ran
SELECT * FROM Employees,

346
00:18:09.400 --> 00:18:13.470
it defaulted to putting that DBO in there,
and it worked for me, right.

347
00:18:13.470 --> 00:18:16.050
You can actually change
a users default schema.

348
00:18:16.050 --> 00:18:18.650
So, if you've got a user that's in HR, and

349
00:18:18.650 --> 00:18:21.060
you know they're always
querying into the HR tables,

350
00:18:21.060 --> 00:18:24.940
and you don't want them to type in that
schema name, you can set that default.

351
00:18:24.940 --> 00:18:28.550
If you do that, they'll have to make sure
to type DBO dot whenever they reference

352
00:18:28.550 --> 00:18:31.170
anything else but as far as HR stuff,
they won't have to do it.

353
00:18:31.170 --> 00:18:34.890
And you know I can't remember if you're
gonna do it for the GUI or not, let's see.

354
00:18:34.890 --> 00:18:37.541
So if I go into my database,
we'll learn something here on the show.

355
00:18:37.541 --> 00:18:43.040
[LAUGH] And if I go into my users and
I take somebody like Daniel, right?

356
00:18:43.040 --> 00:18:46.610
And let's see,
will it let me pull up your properties?

357
00:18:46.610 --> 00:18:47.640
And, no, all right.

358
00:18:47.640 --> 00:18:53.600
So you'd have to do this through a query.

359
00:18:53.600 --> 00:18:57.790
When it comes to permissions, there's a
lot of stuff that doesn't work in the GUI.

00:18:57.790 --> 00:19:00.860
But notice here I just did a script user.

And so it's got CREATE USER [dlowrie] FOR

LOGIN [dlowrie] cuz he's

I can also do an ALTER USER

So now whenever he references
an object and leaves off the schema,

00:19:20.590 --> 00:19:22.070
it would default to HR.

00:19:22.070 --> 00:19:24.580
So you can change somebody's default to

00:19:24.580 --> 00:19:28.070
kind of overcome that argument of somebody

370
00:19:28.070 --> 00:19:29.900
But the reality is they just
need to stop being lazy.

371
00:19:29.900 --> 00:19:31.390
It's a great security feature.

372
00:19:31.390 --> 00:19:32.790
It's one you should take advantage of.

373
00:19:32.790 --> 00:19:34.870
It's been around for over ten years now,

374
00:19:34.870 --> 00:19:38.190
so I think most people should
have adopted it by this point.

375
00:19:38.190 --> 00:19:41.980
But you'd be surprised people are always
hesitant to change databases cuz the data

376
00:19:41.980 --> 00:19:43.000
is so critical and so

377
00:19:43.000 --> 00:19:46.210
important that there's plenty of
people that are still running,

00:19:46.210 --> 00:19:50.280
basically configured the same way they
were back on SQL six, five, or earlier.

379
00:19:50.280 --> 00:19:52.150
>> Now Don, losing access to data or

380
00:19:52.150 --> 00:19:54.340
losing data gives people
heart complications.

381
00:19:54.340 --> 00:19:55.640
I know you know that.

382
00:19:55.640 --> 00:19:58.990
So I can understand why people
would hesitant to move that but

383
00:19:58.990 --> 00:20:01.620
obviously I think you've done
a really good job of showing

384
00:20:01.620 --> 00:20:04.700
why this would be a beneficial thing,
especially if you're,

385
00:20:04.700 --> 00:20:07.530
like you said, you're moving into a new
database, maybe you've got that old and

386
00:20:07.530 --> 00:20:10.920
tried and true and hard to teach an old
dog new tricks, we understand that.

387
00:20:10.920 --> 00:20:13.180
But if you're starting something new,
you start implementing this,

388
00:20:13.180 --> 00:20:17.450
because it really seems to me like
this is a, we're building templates.

389
00:20:17.450 --> 00:20:21.500
And with that template, it removes or
reduces at least, a lot of my

390
00:20:21.500 --> 00:20:25.270
administrative headache of having to go
in here and go okay we got a new user.

391
00:20:25.270 --> 00:20:27.840
Now I've got to set permissions on this,

00:20:27.840 --> 00:20:30.280
this when all I have to do

00:20:30.280 --> 00:20:34.670
which then has that role put in it

00:20:34.670 --> 00:20:35.920
Boom, I'm done.

00:20:35.920 --> 00:20:40.430
All my work is taken care of, I spend a

396
00:20:40.430 --> 00:20:42.520
>> Yeah, and
that's really what it boils down to,

397
00:20:42.520 --> 00:20:43.850
is reducing administrative effort.

398
00:20:43.850 --> 00:20:47.060
If you don't wanna have to come in here
and keep redoing the same thing over and

00:20:47.060 --> 00:20:51.100
over again, the schemas are what helps
as far as permissions are concerned.

400
00:20:51.100 --> 00:20:54.870
As far as everything else, the end users
really don't benefit from schemas,

401
00:20:54.870 --> 00:20:57.480
it does kind of annoy the end users,
cuz they have to type that extra thing and

402
00:20:57.480 --> 00:20:59.470
they don't necessarily see
the benefit out of it.

403
00:20:59.470 --> 00:21:03.030
But in terms of security, ease of effort,
that's where schemas really shine.

404
00:21:03.030 --> 00:21:07.680
So remember that we can set
permissions directly on tables.

405
00:21:07.680 --> 00:21:10.196
We can set permissions directly
on views and stored procedures,

406
00:21:10.196 --> 00:21:11.255
you can certainly do that.

407
00:21:11.255 --> 00:21:13.639
You can assign the permissions
to individual users, and

408
00:21:13.639 --> 00:21:15.383
you can assign the permissions to roles.

409
00:21:15.383 --> 00:21:18.499
Right, roles are better,
because you can move users in and

410
00:21:18.499 --> 00:21:22.361
out of roles to use those permissions,
but at the end of the day if you can,

411
00:21:22.361 --> 00:21:24.600
set your permissions on a schema.

412
00:21:24.600 --> 00:21:27.960
And that's because the schema can be
applied to more than one object, and

413
00:21:27.960 --> 00:21:30.170
that's going to save you time and
reduce mistakes.

414
00:21:30.170 --> 00:21:31.490
So that's the way you need to do it.

415
00:21:31.490 --> 00:21:32.420

00:21:32.420 --> 00:21:33.030

This is one of the episodes that I like
a lot because of well that's really

00:21:36.949 --> 00:21:38.244
practical, you know.

This is stuff you can use, you can really
hit the ground running with it and

00:21:41.510 --> 00:21:45.250
implement it into your environment as
of today at the end of this taping.

So thank you so much for that Don,

we will, looking at the clock though looks

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain server and database auditing when using Azure SQL. First they go over how to enable server level auditing, taking you step-by-step through the Azure web portal. Next they show you how to enable auditing at the database level which can have certain advantages over auditing the server. They also explore the threat detection system to help secure your Azure SQL deployments.
episodes.title: Database Auditing

unfortunately it's something that

00:29:46.720 --> 00:29:48.120

00:29:48.120 --> 00:29:50.200

00:29:50.200 --> 00:29:51.860

00:29:51.860 --> 00:29:54.040

00:29:54.040 --> 00:29:57.250

00:29:57.250 --> 00:30:02.130

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel go over deploying applications to Azure. They begin by showing you how to deploy a fully functional web app from start to finish, all while using the Azure Marketplace, prebuilt application profiles (specifically mojoPortal). They also show you how you can develop your own app by using Visual Studio Community edition and connecting to Azure with your in-house apps.
